01.01.title: Routine Patient Care
01.01.content:
1. Respond to the scene in a safe manner:
• Use information available from the dispatcher, including 911 EMD nature and priority information, consider scene safety and pre-arrival assessment and treatment of the patient.
• Request appropriate additional resources, including advanced life support (ALS) response / intercept if available and the patient may benefit from
ALS care.
• Use of emergency warning lights and sirens should be used with discretion and only as appropriate for the nature of the response and given information, including 911 EMD priority information.
2. Approach the scene cautiously and assess scene safety:
• If a hazard is identified, request appropriate assistance and maintain scene safety through appropriate measures including the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) as indicated. If the scene is unsafe, stage until hazards / threats are mitigated.
• Use standard precautions for all patient contacts. Standard precautions include, depending on the anticipated degree or exposure, the use of gloves, gowns, mask, and eye protection or a face shield. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after each patient contact. Institute transmission based precautions as indicated in Table 1 below.
• Bring all necessary equipment to the patient.
3. Utilize the Major Incident Protocol, if indicated based the number of patients and/or need for resources.
4. Determine if the patient(s) meet pediatric or adult criteria by age. A pediatric ti patient is defined as a patient less than 16 years of age. For patients ≤
E kg/80 lbs., use a pediatric dosing device (Broselow Handtevy or other). If the Broselow Pediatric Emergency Resuscitation Tape is used, patients taller than the length of the tape should receive weight based medication dosing ti until the age of 16 years old or their total body weight is ≥50kg. Some special needs patients may require continued use of pediatric protocols regardless of age.
5. For trauma patients, evaluate the mechanism of injury (MOI) and employ spinal precautions (if indicated, follow the Spinal Precautions Protocol).
6. Obtain and document the patient’s chief complaint (CC), history of the present illness (HPI), past medical history (PMH), current medications
(including over-the-counter medications) and allergies to medications.
7. Perform a primary assessment and obtain vital signs. Vital signs shall include at least blood pressure (BP), palpated pulse, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation as measured by oximeter (SpO ). Temperature (oral, rectal, axillary, or esophageal probe) should be obtained and documented when available and in all critically ill or injured patients.
8. Perform a secondary assessment. The secondary assessment may consist of focused examination for isolated injuries.
9. Treat life-threatening conditions, in the order in which they are identified.
Manage all conditions as indicated per the age appropriate protocols.
10. All patients shall have their level of pain assessed and documented using an age appropriate pain scale (see age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol).
11. Pain, nausea and vomiting should be managed following age appropriate
Patient Comfort Protocols.
12. Provide airway management when indicated following age appropriate
Airway Management Protocols. All patients with an advanced airway (BIAD,
ETT, etc.), including interfacility transfer patients, must have the airway monitored with quantitative waveform capnography and documented in the
PCR.
13. For patients with dyspnea, chest pain, weakness, abdominal pain or other symptoms of possible cardiac etiology and/or with a SpO of <94%, oxygen should be administered via appropriate delivery device to maintain the SpO in a range of 94-99%. During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) oxygen should be administered at the highest FiO possible. Once return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) is achieved, the FiO should be titrated to the lowest concentration required to maintain the SpO in a range of 94-99%.
14. Advanced life support (ALS) EMS healthcare professionals may establish intravenous (IV) access in any unstable or potentially unstable patient or when required for protocol directed therapeutic intervention (e.g., analgesia, treatment of nausea or vomiting, etc.). 0.9% saline solution is the fluid of choice for “keep vein open” (KVO) purposes and limited fluid boluses. Unless otherwise directed by protocol, Lactated Ringer’s is the fluid of choice for significant fluid resuscitation for shock and burn injury. The KVO rate for adult patients is 20-30 ml/hour and for pediatric patients 10-20 ml/hr. Flow rates should be adjusted as directed by protocol. When appropriate, an r intermittent needle therapy (INT) device (a.k.a. saline lock) may be placed in lieu of an infusing IV. Intraosseous (IO) access is these protocols and standing t orders interchangeable with IV access and reference to the IV route of ti medication administration is inclusive of the IO route.
15. Pediatric maintenance IV fluids should be calculated as follows: 4ml/kg for the
E first 10 kg + 2 ml for the second 10 kg plus 1 ml for each additional kg.
ti
16. All intravenous medication and electrolyte infusions, unless exempted in
Appendix 09.01 , must be administered via an electronic infusion pump. See
Appendix 09.01 for Standard Concentrations for IV Admixtures.
17. A multi-lead ECG (≥12 lead) should be obtained in any patient presenting with signs or symptoms suggestive of cardiac ischemia/infarction (chest pain or discomfort, known or suspected anginal equivalent, weakness, abdominal pain, etc.) and in all patients post medical cardiac arrest with ROSC.
18. All procedures, regardless of success, shall be documented on the patient care report (PCR). Documentation shall include, at a minimum: the procedure, the device used, anatomic location, number of attempts, healthcare professional performing the procedure, and any noted complications.
19. Communicate with MEDICAL CONTROL, as indicated, and/or to provide entry .
notification to the receiving hospital facility. EMS healthcare professionals may consult directly with a MEDICAL CONTROL physician any time they feel such communication may be helpful in the care of a patient. Entry notification to the receiving hospital facility shall occur via electronic communication utilizing the RI Patient Tracking System (PTS). It may also occur via direct voice contact utilizing telephonic or radio communication.
20. Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility
(see Table 2 - Point of Entry - Specialized Hospital Emergency Facilities).
Patients in respiratory or cardiac arrest should be transported to the nearest Hospital Emergency Facility unless otherwise directed by MEDICAL CONTROL.
EMS healthcare professionals should recognize and consider, that absent an acute life threatening condition or a condition requiring transportation to specialized care facility, the most appropriate transport destination may be facility at which the patient is followed or receives care (this facility may not be the nearest geographically).
21. Some patients who are older than the pediatric age limit with chronic medical conditions may request or require transportation to a Pediatric Specialty Care Facility. Contact Medical Control at the facility to discuss destination options.
22. During patient transport:
• Stretcher patients shall be secured in an appropriate restraint system providing both transverse and longitudinal protection. Straps are required at the patient’s knees, hips, and over the shoulders.
• Ambulance cots shall be positioned at the lowest possible position during patient transport and other movement of the patient.
• Seated patients shall be restrained with a lap and chest safety belt restraining system.
• Patient transport is limited to one patient per ambulance, unless situation meets the Major Incident Protocol criteria.
• Pediatric patients of appropriate age, height or weight shall be transported utilizing a restraint system (child safety seat) compliant with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards (FMVSS). The car safety seat shall be properly affixed to a stretcher with the head section elevated or to vehicle seat, unless the patient requires immobilization of the spinal column, pelvis, or lower extremities; or the patient requires resuscitation or management of a critical problem.
• All heavy items and equipment (e.g., cardiac monitors, oxygen cylinders) in the patient care compartment of the ambulance shall be secured following the manufactures specifications.
ti
• Emergency warning lights and sirens should only be used when transporting patients with acute life threatening conditions requiring time sensitive interventions.
E 23. The following may be used as a reference for pediatric age appropriate systolic ti
blood pressure:
Neonate >60 mmHg Infant to 1 year >70 mmHg
1-10 years >70 + (2 x age in years)
>10 years >90 mmHg
24. A face-to-face verbal report (hand-off) detailing the patient’s chief complaint, abnormal assessment findings, EMS interventions, and the patient’s response to treatment shall be given to a licensed healthcare professional (i.e., RN,
APRN, PA, MD, DO) at the receiving facility.
25. All care shall be documented in accordance with the Documentation Protocol on a PCR.
26. Direct patient care provided by a non-transporting RI licensed ambulance (i.e., fire suppression unit, ALS intercept, etc.) must be documented by the completion of a PCR by a licensed EMS healthcare professional staffing the unit and providing care. This may result in the generation of two PCRs within one service for the same patient/incident.

Notes
• Hand hygiene is required before and after each patient contact for all patients.

01.02.title: Documentation
01.02.content:
Recognition:
• Documentation is the highest level of the EMS healthcare professional’s accountability.
• The EMS patient care report (PCR) is part of the patient’s permanent medical record and is often examined by other healthcare professionals for important and valuable information.
• The detail and accuracy of a patient’s PCR is reflective of the quality and credibility of the EMS healthcare professionals completing the documentation.
• EMS documentation establishes compliance with or deviation from the established standard of care.
1. All patient contacts with a RI licensed ambulance service must be documented.
2. All documentation must be performed electronically utilizing a National
Emergency Medical Services Information System (NEMSIS) compliant software platform. The version will be determined by the Center for EMS.
3. The use of paper documentation is only acceptable in the event of electronic documentation failure. Paper documentation may not be used as
“placeholder” for electronic documentation.
4. Receiving facilities shall be provided a completed copy of the patient care report (PCR) proximate to patient arrival. In the event this is not possible, the
PCR will be completed and provided to the receiving facility as soon as possible and no greater than two (2) hours after patient hand-off. An explanation in the narrative section of the PCR should explain any delay in the ti provision of a PCR to a receiving facility and should indicate the means used to deliver the report and confirm that it was received.
5. PCR data shall be transmitted or otherwise provided to the Center of
Emergency Medical Services (CEMS) in the timeframe specified in the Rhode Island Code of Regulations, Emergency Medical Services [216-RICR-20-10-2].
6. In addition to required patient demographics, the following shall be documented in the narrative section of the PCR for each patient contact (if a particular data point is not applicable or is unobtainable, it should be
documented as such):
E ⃝ ie ch co ism pl
;
jury (if applicable);
Source of information (if not from the patient);
History of present illness or injury:
Past medical history;
Family and social history (only if relevant);
Medications;
Medication or other significant allergies;
Physical examination findings (may be a focused examination for isolated injuries/complaints); .
ECG interpretation and other point of care lab data (i.e. finger stick blood glucose);
Assessment (presumptive field diagnosis); and
All interventions and an evaluation of the effect or response.
7. All procedures and procedure attempts shall be documented. Documentation
of the following is required for all procedures:
Anatomic location (if applicable);
Number of attempts;
+/- success;
Name of the healthcare professional(s) performing or attempting the procedure;
Complications;
Patient response, if applicable.
Documentation elements specified in individual procedure protocols and standing orders shall also be included.
8. Medication administration documentation shall include the name of the medication, dose administered, route, time of administration, name of the administering healthcare professional, medication effect, and any adverse effects.
9. At least two complete sets of vital signs shall be documented for transported patients and one complete set for non-transported patients (pulse, respirations, auscultated blood pressure, and the SpO at a minimum). Vital signs should be repeated and documented after drug administration, prior to patient transfer, and as needed during transport. For patients <3 y. o., blood pressure measurement is not required for all patients, but should be measured if possible, especially in critically ill patients, for whom blood pressure measurement may guide treatment decisions. For critically ill or injured patients, vital signs should be documented at least every ten minutes and whenever significant changes are noted. The use of “WNL” is inappropriate and should not be utilized as a substitute for the documentation of measured vital signs.
10. ECG and EtCO tracings must be uploaded into the PCR.
11. A transfer of care signature must be obtained from a licensed healthcare professional at the receiving healthcare facility. Additionally, the name and ti licensure level of the healthcare professional receiving the patient during transfer of care must be documented in the signature block section of the
PCR.
12. Prior to submission, all PCRs shall be complete and meet a validation score of 100 percent unless vital information such as the patient’s name, date of birth or home address are not able to be ascertained from the scene. In this case, the pertinent data elements should be left blank and placeholders shall not be used (i.e., do not use placeholders such as “Jane Doe”, “Unknown”,
1/1/1900, etc.). The PCR author shall then contact the appropriate authorities in a timely manner to obtain the missing data and then enter it into the PCR.
Note any amendments in an addendum.
13. Any addendums or amendments to the PCR shall be dated, timed and signed by the author.
14. It is recognized that there are circumstances, particularly involving traumatic mechanisms of injury, as in the case of motor vehicle crashes or industrial accidents, when it is extremely helpful to the Emergency Department healthcare professionals to visualize the scene. Photographs can become part of the patient's hospital medical record. However, identifiable no persons should be visible in the photograph. Other identifying information, such as license plates, should also be excluded, if possible. Patient care and transport should not be delayed to obtain photographs. Additionally,
EMS healthcare professionals shall not share photographs or any identifiable information that could result in the disclosure of protected patient health information.
Reference:
* https://www.hipaajournal.com/hipaa-photography-rules/

01.03.title: Medical Control
01.03.content:
1. The direction of prehospital care at the scene of an emergency is the responsibility of the most appropriately trained senior, or highest licensed level
EMS healthcare professional present. Care at the scene should be provided in collaborative nature amongst all EMS healthcare professionals present in the best interest of the patient following the Rhode Island Statewide EMS
Protocols and Standing Orders and on-line medical direction.
2. If an EMS physician (EMS agency medical director or designee, EMS fellow or other recognized EMS physician) is present, collaborate with the physician in providing patient care by following their on-scene Medical Control.
3. If a patient’s private physician is present and assumes responsibility for the
patient’s care:
• Defer to the orders of the physician, providing the orders are within the scope of care of the EMS healthcare professional.
4. If another physician is present (a physician who is not the patient’s physician or an EMS physician) and has appropriately identified themselves as a licensed physician and has demonstrated their willingness to assume responsibility for
the patient’s care and document their interventions:
• Keep in mind that most physicians assisting with EMS care are well intentioned. i
• Defer to the wishes of the physician if in agreement with RI Statewide EMS
Protocols and Standing Orders.
• If the physician’s wishes differs from care outlined in the RI Statewide EMS
E Protocols and Standing Orders or, there is disagreement between the EMS healthcare professional and the physician, online medical control should be established and the physician at the scene should be placed in communication with the medical control physician.
• The online medical control physician has the option of managing the case entirely, working with the physician, or allowing the physician to assume responsibility.
• If there is disagreement between the physician and the online medical control physician, the EMS healthcare professional shall defer to the online medical control physician. .
• If the treatment at the scene differs from that outlined in the RI Statewide
EMS Protocols and Standing Orders or there is disagreement between the
EMS healthcare professionals and the physician and online medical control cannot be established, the physician should agree in advance to accompany the patient to the hospital, if possible.

01.04.title: Biological Death
01.04.content:
Recognition:
• An adult patient without vital signs and with at least one of the following: rigor mortis (rigid stiffness of the body), fixed lividity, obvious injury incompatible with life (e.g., decapitation, transection) or obvious changes of decomposition (i.e., bloating, skin slippage, extensive green or black skin discoloration).
• A pediatric patient without vital signs and with at least one of the following: obvious injury incompatible with life (e.g., decapitation, transection) or obvious changes of decomposition (i.e., bloating, skin slippage, extensive green or black skin discoloration).
• Patients not meeting the above criteria shall receive resuscitative care following the age appropriate Cardiac Arrest Protocol, unless the patient or the patient’s qualified health care decision maker, pursuant to the Rhode Island Code of Regulations, [216-RICR-20-15-4] has a completed Medical Orders for Life Sustaining Treatment (MOLST) form, a signed Do Not Resuscitate order (DNR) or the patient has Comfort One status. Manage patients with MOLST, DNR or
Comfort One status per the MOLST / Comfort One Protocol.
• By recognizing the evidence of lifelessness (as above, in recognition), EMS healthcare professionals have made a determination of death. The determination of death by EMS healthcare professionals does not constitute pronouncement or
E certification of death, which are the responsibility of a physician or licensed independent healthcare professional (advanced practice registered nurse (APRN) or a physician assistant (PA), who at the time is practicing in a physician supervised role).
• Once a determination of death has been made, responsibility for the patient lies l with local or state law enforcement. Law enforcement is responsible for contacting the Medical Examiner’s Office. The body should not be removed from the scene and the scene should be disturbed as little as possible.
• EMS documentation must include the specific criteria on which the determination of death was made.
• Follow Deceased Persons Protocol.
NOTES:
• Fixed lividity (purple/blue discoloration in gravitationally dependent parts of the body), does not change appearance with palpation.
• Cyanosis and skin changes associated with hypoperfusion should not be confused with fixed lividity.
• Isolated jaw stiffness is not rigor mortis. Check major joints such as the shoulders and knees for rigor mortis.

01.05.title: Mobile Integrated Health / Community Paramedicine
01.05.content:
Introduction
• Emergency Medical Services healthcare professionals have traditionally functioned as mobile healthcare unit and are a logical resource for providing healthcare to the community as an extension of the primary care and public health network, provided a formal process is followed, as outlined in this protocol.
• This protocol enables an EMS agency to form a coalition of partners for the purpose of providing community-based health care services within the scope of practice of the EMS healthcare professional.
• A community that is experiencing a gap in healthcare services, as evidenced by a community needs assessment, may elect to utilize the capabilities of the EMS system in collaboration with public health, primary care healthcare professionals and/or a hospital. i
• Only EMS agencies who have met the requirements of this protocol may operate under i these guidelines. Health is available to provide consultation and support to Mobile Integrated Healthcare -
Community Paramedicine initiatives.
Description of Mobile Integrated Healthcare (MIH) - Community Paramedicine (CP)
• MIH-CP is the provision of healthcare using patient-centered mobile resources in the out-of- hospital environment.
• The MIH-CP concept is envisioned to be an organized system of services, based on local
/ need.
• The purpose of the initiative is to address the unmet needs of individuals who are experiencing intermittent health care issues. It is not intended to address long-term medical or nursing case management and is not a replacement for traditional home health services. MIH-CP Licensing Requirements
• EMS agencies wishing to provide MIH-CP services must be a licensed emergency medical services agency pursuant to Rhode Island General Laws §23-4.1 and the Rhode Island Code of t Regulations, Emergency Medical Services [216-RICR-20-10-2]. r
• The services must be provided by an Emergency Medical Technicians (EMT), Advanced EMTs,
Advanced EMT-Cardiacs or Paramedics who are integrated into the local health care system, working in a collaborative manner with physicians, mid-level healthcare professionals, home health care agencies and other community health colleagues, within their respective scope l of practice.
• EMS healthcare professionals shall perform services within their scope of practice.
• Oversight all activities must be provided by emergency and primary care physicians. Goal of the MIH-CP program
• Provide urgent follow-up care when other home health resources and services are not an option.
• Be part of a multidisciplinary team evaluating the needs of individuals who frequently utilize
EMS in order to reduce that frequency while improving the quality and effectiveness of care delivered.
• Assess patients not recently seen by a physician, advanced practice registered nurse (APRN) or physician assistant (PA) for the need for chronic disease screening, and in collaboration . with a primary care practice, help to initiate that screening.
• Or, other goal(s) as approved by the Center for EMS.
Assessing Community Needs
• EMS agencies are encouraged to work with their communities to assess their needs and en- sure the MIH-CP program goals align. MIH-CP is intended as a means to utilize EMS re- sources to address community healthcare needs. It is understood that the mix and delivery method of MIH-CP services will vary from community to community, as needs vary.
• A fundamental element of establishing a MIH-CP program, therefore, is that the EMS agen- cy assess what the unaddressed or under-addressed health needs of their community might be. It is only then that the agency can determine whether it has the staff, finances, and oth- er resources to address some of those needs.
Eligibility of MIH-CP Patient
• EMS agencies establishing an MIH-CP program are encouraged to develop their own eligibil- ity criteria based on the scope of their MIH-CP program.
• Patient must be enrolled in the Rhode Island Health Information Exchange (HIE) (CurrentCare or other HIE designated by the Director). If a patient is not enrolled, EMS agencies can encourage patient to enroll in the HIE as part of the MIH-CP enrollment pro- cess.
• Patient must not be eligible for home nursing care or home care services unless referred by a PCP (e.g., pending initiation of home health services). MIH-CP Program Scope
/
The roles within the scope of MIH-CP shall include the following, but not limited to:
• Assessments within the scope of practice of the MIH-CP practitioner, as ordered by the cli- ent's PCP or as established within the approved MIH-CP program.
• Screening and education for chronic disease as well as mental and behavioral health in pa- tients who are home bound when other resources are not available or have failed; l
• PARAMEDICS and AEMT-C only: administration of immunizations and vaccinations for cli- ents in the home (e.g., seasonal influenza and COVID vaccines), in accordance with the Immunization Protocol, or where the vaccine is provided by a primary care practice, trans- ported appropriately, and the EMS agency is enrolled in the RIDOH State Supplied Vaccine (SSV) program.
• Urgent laboratory specimen collection (i.e., blood draws and cultures), as requested by the primary care practice;
• Public health functions, such as evaluation of patients enrolled in a direct active monitoring or direct observed therapy program prescribed by RIDOH or evaluation of patients based on approved MIH-CP program.
• By protocol and after real time consultation with a primary care practice healthcare profes- sional, EMS medical director or approved MIH-CP patient interaction plan, provide on-scene treatment without transportation; and
• Home safety assessments, including prevention of falls and fire safety. Referral Process of MIH-CP
• EMS initiated: as a result of frequent EMS calls from specific patients with approval from the
PCP or as established within the approved MIH-CP program. To make a referral, the EMS agency shall contact the patient’s PCP or case manager to suggest the referral, if applicable.
Otherwise, the patient should be enrolled as established within the approved MIH-CP program.
• Emergency department (ED) initiated: referral from emergency department (ED) physician upon discharge, provided that a memorandum of understanding is already in place with that emergency department and a primary care practice with an MOU is included in the follow-up plan at the time of the referral.
• Primary care professional (PCP) initiated: the patient requires urgent assessment based on phone assessment by the primary care practice, the patient does not currently have access to or is ineligible for home nursing care or home care services, and requires frequent needs that i can be addressed in the community via MIH-CP, or the patient requires follow-up assessment i and care that can be fulfilled through MIH-CP.
• Other programs: referral from a home nursing care healthcare professional or home care healthcare professional as a result of ineligibility for these services.
• RI Department of Health (RIDOH): referral for public health functions. Field Treatment Without Transportation
• EMS healthcare professionals, in direct consultation with the patient’s PCP, EMS Medical Director or approved MIH-CP patient interaction plan are allowed to administer field treatment without transportation of the patient to a hospital facility.
• The PCP shall provide on-line medical control to the EMS healthcare professional to authorize
/ field treatment, provided said treatment is within the scope of practice of the on-scene EMS healthcare professional and is consistent with the Rhode Island Statewide EMS Protocols and Standing Orders.
Transportation to a non-hospital facility
A patient may be transported to a non-hospital facility, including a health clinic, primary care
office, urgent care facility or substance abuse treatment center only when:
• The patient’s PCP provides authorization via direct consultation, or;
• Certain clinical criteria have been met, particularly for transportation to a substance abuse treatment center, or;
• Authorization is provided by medical control, or;
• As approved in MIH-CP patient interaction plan.
Establishing Medical Direction
• The MIH-CP program must establish a collaborative working relationship between the EMS Medical Director or designee, who will be responsible for medical policy, operations and continuous quality improvement, and medical direction for MIH-CP services.
• The leadership role of the primary care healthcare professional in every patient-EMS healthcare professional interaction plays a pivotal role in the design of MIH-CP and is requirement for MIH-CP programs in which services require primary care interaction. Developing a Training Plan
• EMS agencies are encouraged to develop MIH-CP training that can aid EMS healthcare professionals to be more effective in their communities. EMS healthcare professionals will benefit from training that includes cultural competency, health literacy, behavioral health, community awareness, home health care, MIH-CP education and specific program topic education.
• EMS agencies shall designate who will be responsible for training, oversight, and coordination as well as their qualifications.
• There must be a continuing education and credentialing process in place, with documentation of each EMS healthcare professional’s participation.
• Such a process shall be approved by the EMS service Medical Director(s) and shall be reported to the Center for EMS Training Coordinator.
Continuous Quality Improvement Program /
• The EMS service shall implement a continuous quality improvement (CQI) program specifically for the MIH-CP program that incorporates all the components of an EMS CQI program as specified in the Rhode Island Code of Regulations, Emergency Medical Services [216-RICR-20- 10-2]. Data Collection Data collection is a critical component of a quality MIH-CP program. EMS agencies shall follow minimum standards for data collection in accordance with sections within the Routine Patient
Care and Documentation. In addition, provide answers to the following: t
• Describe what data demonstrates the need for this project, if any.
• Describe your agency’s ability to collect the following required data: age, race/ethnicity, gender.
• Describe other data to be collected to demonstrate the impact of this project on the population served.
• Describe the data reporting plan and how the RI Center for EMS will receive data and reports.
• EMS agencies should also be equipped and prepared to report on data involving the number of participants enrolled, number of participants active in the program, number of participants treated for MIH-CP enrollment vs. transported for emergency need, plus any other data that RI DOH deems necessary. Documentation
• The EMS agency will participate in electronic data collection as required in the Rhode Island
Code of Regulations, Emergency Medical Services [216-RICR-20-10-2].
• Electronic patient care reports of all MIH-CP program patient encounters must be submitted . via the MIH-CP module in RI-EMSIS.
• If, using their own discretion, a EMS healthcare professional decides to activate the E-911 system for emergency treatment and transport for appropriate care, a patient care report must be submitted via the RI-EMSIS. Requirements to establish a MIH-CP program in Rhode Island
Each EMS service that wants to establish an MIH-CP program must submit a plan to the RI Center for EMS MIH-CP coordinator via an online application. The plan should include the following
elements (application may have additional requirements):
1. General Project Description
• Describe the community or communities to be served, the name of the MIH-CP program (e.g., South County MIH-CP), the service’s base location(s), the unmet community health needs that will be addressed, the current community health team collaborators and methodology for addressing the need, including any enhancements of the EMS response system that will result.
2. Medical Direction
• Provide information related to a collaborative working relationship between the EMS agency and the EMS medical director, including the role of the medical director in the MIH-CP / program.
3. Patient Interaction Plan
• Describe the nature of anticipated patient and EMS healthcare professional interaction.
• Specify how the patient community will be educated to have realistic expectations of the EMS practitioner and their interactions.
• Establish community patient needs, and goals and objectives to meet those needs.
4. Staffing Plan
• Describe who will be providing MIH-CP services and how these services fit within the normal
EMS staffing of the service.
• Describe the type of schedule MIH-CP services will be made available to the community.
• Describe how staffing arrangements will be funded.
5. Training and Education Plan
• Describe what training and education will be provided to enable EMS healthcare professionals to deliver the services described above.
• List the objectives and outcomes of the training and education plan.
• Document who will be responsible for training, education, oversight, and coordination, as well as their qualifications.
6. Continuous Quality Improvement Program
• Establish a continuous quality improvement program led by the medical director.
7. Data Collection
• Describe what data demonstrates the need for this project, if any.
• Describe the data to be collected to demonstrate the impact of this project on the population served. Documentation
• Describe the documentation process for the MIH-CP program.
Coordinating Care and MIH-CP
• Describe how care will be coordinated with patients enrolled in MIH-CP program. Referral Process & Eligibility
• Identify the MIH-CP program referral process.
• Describe the eligibility criteria for patients participating in your agency MIH-CP program.
/
NOTES:
• At no time are EMS healthcare professionals allowed to perform activities not included in the skill level of their scope of practice. MIH-CP functions expand the role of EMS healthcare professionals, not the scope of practice.
• If at any time there is any doubt as to whether the patient needs care at a hospital-based emergency department or not, immediate transportation shall be provided to an appropriate hospital emergency facility.
• Communities participating in the MIH-CP program are also strongly encouraged to be leaders and participants in improving community-based care, e.g., the HeartSafe .
Community program, opioid overdose prevention and blood pressure screenings, and partnering with primary care to coordinate MIH-CP services.

01.06.title: Emergency Medical Responder (EMR) Scope of Practice
01.06.content:
1. The Emergency Medical Responder (EMR) scope of practice shall consist of the
following:
a. Basic patient assessment including measurement of vital signs
(temperature, pulse rate, respiratory rate and blood pressure) b. Airway maintenance utilizing the head-tilt chin lift, jaw thrust and modified chin lift maneuvers c. Oropharyngeal airway insertion d. Bag-valve-mask ventilation e. Relief of foreign body airway obstruction utilizing abdominal/chest thrusts and back blows ti f. Suctioning of the upper airway g. Administration of oxygen via nasal cannula or non-rebreather oxygen mask h. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) i. Use of an automated external defibrillator (AED) j. Hemorrhage control utilizing direct pressure, tourniquet or hemostatic dressing k. Manual cervical stabilization of suspected cervical spine injuries l. Manual stabilization of extremity fractures m. Assisting with uncomplicated obstetrical deliveries ) n. Administration of intranasal naloxone for suspected opioid overdose o. Administration of nerve antidotes via autoinjector for self or peer care
( p. Administration of epinephrine via autoinjector for suspected anaphylactic
E reaction q. Ocular irrigation for chemical eye injuries r. Application of simple dressings and bandages for wound care.
2. EMRs may provide care within the defined EMR scope of practice when applicable in all protocols contained herein.

01.07.title: Advanced Emergency Medical Technician (AEMT) Scope of Practice
01.07.content:
1. The AEMT scope of practice shall consist of the following:
a. All of the skills of the Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) b. Establishing intravenous and intraosseous vascular access c. Maintenance of non-medicated intravenous IV fluids d. Administration of medication via the inhalation route e. Administration medications via the IV/IO route f. Administration of crystalloid IV fluid blouses for hypotension g. Administration of medications via the intramuscular route ti h. Administration of medication via the sublingual route
i. Administration of the following medications:
• Nitroglycerin via the sublingual route
• Dextrose 10% f
• Epinephrine (1mg/1ml) IM
• Epinephrine (1mg/10ml) IV/IO for cardiac arrest (non-shockable rhythms)
• Ondansetron
• Glucagon
• Naloxone IV/IN
• Nitrous oxide
A • Thiamine (optional) i
2. The AEMT may provide care within the defined AEMT scope of practice where applicable in all protocols contained herein.
M
T

02.01.title: Acute Neurologic Event with Evidence of Increased ICP
02.01.content:
02.01 Acute Neurologic Event with Evidence of Increased Intracranial Pressure (ICP)
Recognition:
• Patient with altered mental status (GCS <8), abnormal motor posturing, unilateral or bilat- eral dilation of pupils, +/- bradycardia and/or hypertension.
• Possible etiologies include traumatic brain injury, epidural hematoma, subdural hematoma, subarachnoid hemorrhage, primary intracerebral hemorrhage, tumor, or encephalopathy.
• Routine patient care.
• If feasible, elevate the head of bed to > 30°.
• Avoid obstructions to venous drainage, such as tight cervical collars, securing devices for endotracheal tubes, or a non-midline head position.
• Provide airway management as indicated per the age appropriate Airway Management Protocol.
• Ventilate the patient to maintain an EtCO of 30-35 mmHg (avoid over aggressive hyperventilation), if capnography is not available, ventilate the patient at a rate of
E 14-16 bpm.
• Perform blood glucose analysis and manage hypoglycemia per the age appropriate Diabetic Emergencies Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. i
A • Manage hypotension per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension
Protocol, maintain the MAP ≥ 80 or the SBP ≥ 110.
• Manage hypotension per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension
Protocol, maintain the MAP ≥ 80 or the SBP ≥ 110.
• 3% SALINE (HTS) 3 ml/kg (pediatrics 1ml/kg) IV over 15 minutes.
NOTES:
• Follow and document the patient’s neurologic examination. Convey the patient’s best neurologic examination and any episodes of hypoxia or hypotension during patient hand off.
• Attempt to obtain information related to use of antiplatelet or anticoagulants by the patient.
• Mild hyperventilation (EtCO 30-35 mmHg) is a temporizing means of decreasing ICP and is reserved for patients with evidence of increased ICP/brain herniation. Brain ischemia is worsened by over aggressive hyperventilation. Patients without evidence of increased ICP should be ventilated to maintain normocapnia (EtCO 35-45 mmHg).
• Short isolated episodes of hypoxia or hypotension should be avoided as they can cause secondary brain injury.
• Hyperglycemia is associated with worsened neurologic outcome. Glucose containing solutions should be administered only as indicated for the treatment of hypoglycemia.

02.02.title: Abdominal Pain
02.02.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with complaint of abdominal pain, discomfort or cramping.
• Routine patient care.
• If the history and/or signs and symptoms are suggestive of a cardiac etiology, manage per the Chest Pain-Acute Coronary-Syndrome-STEMI Protocol.
• Manage hypotension, poor perfusion, or shock per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
A • Acquire a multi-lead ECG in any patient ≥ 35 y.o. Manage per the Chest Pain-
Acute Coronary-Syndrome-STEMI Protocol if findings suggest a cardiac etiology.
• Analgesia and antiemetic therapy as indicated per the age appropriate Patient
Comfort Protocol.
NOTES:
• Consider a possible cardiac etiology in patients ≥ 20 y.o., diabetic patients and/or females especially with upper abdominal complaints or vague complaints of GI distress. Maintain a low threshold acquire a multi-lead ECG in these patients.
• Any female within child bearing age (12-50) should be managed as an ectopic pregnancy until such is ruled out.
• Abdominal aortic aneurysm should be considered in any patient ≥ 50 y.o. with abdominal pain, especially those with hypotension, poor perfusion, or shock.
• Mesenteric ischemia may present with severe pain with limited exam findings. Risk factors include age ≥ 60, atrial fibrillation, CHF and atherosclerosis.

02.03.title: Adrenal Insufficiency
02.03.content:
Recognition:
• History of AI/Addison’s disease, HIV/AIDS, sepsis.
• History of long term use of steroids (asthma, COPD, rheumatoid arthritis, organ transplant), use of antifungal agents.
• Hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dehydration, abdominal pain.
• Routine patient care.
• Maintain and promote normothermia by the use of blankets and increasing the ambient temperature if possible.
• Perform blood glucose (bG) analysis and treat as indicated per the age appropriate Diabetic Emergencies Protocol.
• Manage hypotension/shock per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. ffi
• HYDROCORTISONE 100 mg (2 mg/kg, 100 mg maximum for pediatrics) IV r (preferred) or METHYLPREDNISOLONE 125 mg (2 mg/kg, 60 mg maximum for pediatrics) IV or DEXAMETHASONE 10 mg (0.3 mg/kg, 10 mg maximum for pediatrics) IV.
C • Manage hypotension/shock per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension Protocol.
NOTES:
• Consider AI in patients with hypotension refractory to IV fluids and or vasopressors.
• Consider administering a stress dose steroids to patients with a history of AI and any of the following: shock, fever (T>100.4°F) and ill appearing, multisystem trauma, burns (partial/full thickness) > 5% BSA, environmental hypothermia or hyperthermia, or vomiting or diarrhea with evidence of dehydration.

02.04A.title: Allergic Reaction / Anaphylaxis - Adult
02.04A.content:
Recognition:
• History of exposure to an antigen, e.g. bee/wasp sting, shellfish, tree nuts, latex, medication
• Itching, urticaria (hives), angioedema, wheezing, respiratory distress, chest or throat tightness, difficulty swallowing, GI symptoms, hypotension.
Mild Flushing, urticaria, itching, erythema with normal blood pressure and perfusion Flushing, urticaria, itching, erythema plus respiratory (wheezing, dyspnea, Moderate hypoxia) with normal blood pressure and perfusion
+/- skin symptoms depending on perfusion. Possible itching, erythema plus
Severe respiratory (wheezing, dyspnea, hypoxia) or gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain) with hypotension and poor perfusion i
• Routine patient care.
• Assess symptom severity.
• For patients with symptoms of mild severity, monitor and reassess for worsening signs and symptoms.
• For patients with symptoms of moderate severity, consider EPINEPHRINE (1:1000) -
E 0.3 mg IM (lateral thigh) [auto-injector preferred] (avoid in patients > 50 yo or with a history of cardiac disease with mild symptoms only). ti
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing
(additional doses require authorization from MEDICAL CONTROL).
• For patients with severe symptoms, administer EPINEPHRINE (1:1000) 0.3 mg IM
A (lateral thigh) [auto-injector preferred] (for patients > 50 yo or with a history of cardiac disease, administer 0.15 mg) every 5 minutes if no improvement to maximum of 3 doses. Additional doses require authorization from MEDICAL
CONTROL.
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing
(additional doses require authorization from MEDICAL CONTROL).
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
• For patients with symptoms of mild severity, DIPHENHYDRAMINE 50 mg PO/IV/
IM.
• For patients with symptoms of moderate severity: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). DIPHENHYDRAMINE 50 mg IV/IM if not already given PO.
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (may repeat x3).
METHYLPREDNISOLONE 125 mg IV or HYDROCORTISONE 100mg IV.
• For patients with severe symptoms: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses).
C ⃝ NORMAL SALINE 500 ml IV bolus for a SBP <100 mmHg (may repeat to .
maximum of 2L).
DIPHENHYDRAMINE 50 mg IV/IM if not already given PO.
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (may repeat x3).
METHYLPREDNISOLONE 125 mg IV or HYDROCORTISONE 100 mg IV.
Consider GLUCAGON 1-4 mg IV in patients taking a beta antagonist.
• For geriatric patients (≥ 65 yo) consider CETIRIZINE (Zyrtec) 10mg PO as an alternative to DIPHENHYDRAMINE.
• For patients with symptoms of mild severity, DIPHENYDRAMINE 50 mg PO/IV/IM and FAMOTIDINE 20-40 mg PO/IV.
• For patients with symptoms of moderate severity: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). DIPHENHYDRAMINE 50 mg IV/IM if not already given PO.
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (may repeat X3).
FAMOTADINE 20-40 mg PO/IV.
METHYLPREDNISOLONE 125 mg IV or HYDOCORTISONE 100 mg IV or
PREDNISONE 60 mg PO.
• For patients with severe symptoms: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). NORMAL SALINE 500 ml IV bolus for a SBP <100 mmHg (may repeat to
P maximum of 2L maximum).
DIPHENHYDRAMINE 50 mg IV/IM if not already given PO.
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (may repeat x3).
FAMOTIDINE 20-40 mg PO/IV.
○ METHYLPREDNISOLONE 125 mg IV or HYDROCORTISONE 100 mg IV or
PREDNISONE 60 mg PO.
-
Consider GLUCAGON 1-4 mg IV in patients taking a beta antagonist.
For peri-arrest hypotension refractory to IM epinephrine, push-dose
○ ti
EPINEPHRINE 10-20 mcg (1-2 ml EPINEPHRINE 10 mcg/ml) IV every minute followed by an EPINEPHRINE IV infusion at 5-15 mcg/minutes titrated to achieve a SBP of ≥100 or MAP ≥65.
* See NOTES for information regarding treating non-allergic angioedema with TXA
NOTES:
• * TXA 1000mg (1gm) IV over 10 minutes may help treat non-allergic angioedema.
Angioedema may be seen in patients taking ACE inhibitors (ACE-I) [lisinopril, ramipril, captopril, benazepril, quinapril, enalapril]. ACE-I induced angioedema results from an excessive accumulation of bradykinin. This is different from the histamine mediated angioedema associated with allergic/anaphylactic reactions. The use of antihistamines, corticosteroids and epinephrine offer no benefit in ACE-I related angioedema. ACE-I induced angioedema usually starts with focal swelling (e.g., isolated swelling of the tongue or lips). Patients with severe angioedema involving the tongue with airway compromise often require nasotracheal intubation.
• The use of an auto-injector is strongly recommended for the administration of IM epinephrine at all EMS healthcare professional levels, if available.
• Recommended exam: mental status, skin, cardiac, pulmonary.
• If possible, patients with severe symptoms should remain in a supine position.
• Allergic reactions may occur with only respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms without a rash or other skin symptoms/signs.
• Patients with moderate or severe reactions should have IV access established and cardiac monitoring initiated.
• Patients > 50 yo, with a history of cardiac disease, or a heart rate > 150 are at risk for cardiac ischemia following the administration of epinephrine. These patients should have ongoing cardiac monitoring and a multi-lead ECG following the administration of epinephrine.
• In the case of hereditary angioedema (HAE), like ACE-I related angioedema, the use of antihistamines, corticosteroids and epinephrine offer no benefit. Some patients with HAE are prescribed medication which may reverse it. Paramedics may assist the patient with or administer these medication per patient or packaging/prescription instructions.

02.04P.title: Allergic Reaction / Anaphylaxis - Pediatric
02.04P.content:
Recognition:
• History of exposure to an antigen (e.g., bee/wasp sting, shellfish, tree nuts, latex, medication)
• Itching, urticaria (hives) angioedema, wheezing, respiratory distress, chest or throat tightness, difficulty swallowing, GI symptoms, hypotension. Symptom Severity Classification Flushing, urticaria, itching, erythema with normal blood pressure and Mild perfusion Flushing, urticaria, itching, erythema plus respiratory (wheezing, dyspnea, Moderate hypoxia) with normal blood pressure and perfusion +/- skin symptoms depending on perfusion. Possible itching, erythema plus
Severe respiratory (wheezing, dyspnea, hypoxia) or gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain) with hypotension and poor perfusion i
• Routine patient care.
• Assess symptom severity.
• For patients with symptoms of mild severity, monitor and reassess for worsening signs and symptoms. -
• For patients with symptoms of moderate severity, consider EPINEPHRINE (1:1000)
0.15 mg for patients 15-30 kg (33-66 lbs.) or 0.3 mg for patients > 30 kg (66 lbs.) IM ti
[lateral thigh] (auto-injector preferred).
○ ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (additional doses require authorization from MEDICAL CONTROL).
A • For patients with severe symptoms, administer EPINEPHRINE (1:1000) 0.15 for c patients 15-30 kg (33-66 lbs. or 0.3 mg for patients > 30 kg (66 lbs.) IM [lateral] thigh
(auto-injector preferred) every 5 minutes if no improvement to maximum of doses. Additional doses require authorization from MEDICAL CONTROL.
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing
(additional doses require authorization from MEDICAL CONTROL).
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
• For patients with symptoms of mild severity, DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg PO/IV/IM (maximum 50 mg) or CETIRIZINE (Zyrtec) 10 mg PO for children older than 6 years of age.
• For patients with symptoms of moderate severity: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg IV/IM if not already given PO (maximum 50 mg).
○ ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (may i repeat x3). METHYLPREDNISOLONE 2 mg/kg IV (maximum 60 mg) or HYDROCORTISONE 2
C ⃝ mg/kg IV (maximum 100 mg).
• For patients with severe symptoms: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). NORMAL SALINE 20 ml/kg IV bolus, repeat as needed to achieve age appropriate BP (60 ml/kg maximum). DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg IV/IM if not already given PO (maximum 50 mg).
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing (may repeat X3).
METHYLPREDNISOLONE 2 mg/kg IV (maximum 60 mg) or HYDROCORTISONE mg/kg IV (maximum 100 mg).
• For patients with symptoms of mild severity, DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg PO/IV/IM (maximum 50 mg) and FAMOTIDINE 1 mg/kg IV (maximum 40 mg).
• For patients with symptoms of moderate severity: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg PO/IV/IM if not already given PO (maximum mg).
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via SVN for continued wheezing
(may repeat X3).
METHYLPREDNISOLONE 2 mg/kg IV (maximum 60 mg) or HYDROCORTISONE mg/kg IV (maximum 100 mg) or PREDNISONE/PREDNISOLONE (Orapred) 2 mg/ kg PO (maximum 60 mg).
FAMOTIDINE 1 mg/kg IV (maximum 40 mg).
• For patients with severe symptoms: If indicated, continue IM administration of EPINEPHRINE (maximum 3 doses). NORMAL SALINE 20 ml/kg IV bolus, repeat as needed to achieve age appropriate BP (60 ml/kg maximum). DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg IV/IM if not already given PO (maximum 50 mg).
ALBUTEROL 2.5-5 mg (+/- IPRATROPIUM) via nebulizer for continued wheezing
(may repeat X3).
METHYLPREDNISOLONE 2 mg/kg IV (maximum 60 mg) or HYDROCORTISONE
- mg/kg IV (maximum 100 mg) or PREDNISONE/PREDNISOLONE (Orapred) 2 mg/ kg PO (maximum 60 mg). ti FAMOTIDINE 1 mg/kg IV (maximum 40 mg).
For peri-arrest hypotension refractory to IM epinephrine, push-dose
EPINEPHRINE 1 mcg/kg IV [maximum dose 20 mcg] (0.1 ml/kg EPINEPHRINE mcg/ml) every 3-5 minutes followed by an EPINEPHRINE infusion at 0.01-1 mcg/ i kg/minutes titrated to achieve age appropriate BP.
* See NOTES for information regarding treating non-allergic angioedema with TXA.
NOTES:
• * TXA 15mg/kg (maximum 1000mg [1gm]) IV over 10 minutes may help treat non-allergic angioedema. Angioedema may be seen in patients taking ACE inhibitors (ACE-I) [lisinopril, ramipril, captopril, benazepril, quinapril, enalapril]. ACE-I induced angioedema results from an excessive accumulation of bradykinin. This is different then the histamine mediated an- gioedema associated with allergic/anaphylactic reactions. The use of antihistamines, corti- costeroids and epinephrine offer no benefit in ACE-I related angioedema.
• The use of an auto-injector is strongly recommended for the administration of IM epi- nephrine at all EMS healthcare professional levels, if available.
• For patients <15 kg (33 lbs.) with moderate or severe symptoms, paramedics may consider epinephrine (1:1000) 0.01 mg/kg IM.
• If possible, patients with severe symptoms should remain in a supine position.
• Allergic reactions may occur with only respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms without rash or other skin symptoms/signs.
• Patients with moderate or severe reactions should have IV access established and cardiac monitoring initiated.
• Tachycardia (HR >150) is common following administration of epinephrine and/or albut- erol. These patients should have ongoing cardiac monitoring and should have a multi-lead
ECG acquired following the administration of epinephrine.
• Do not withhold epinephrine in a normal healthy child.
• Epinephrine is the single most effective drug to reverse immediate moderate and sever symptoms and should be the first drug administered.
• Diphenhydramine helps rash and itch, steroids take time for effects to be seen.
• ACE-I induced angioedema usually starts with focal swelling (e.g. isolated swelling of the tongue or lips). Patients with severe angioedema involving the tongue with airway compro- mise often require nasotracheal intubation.
• In the case of hereditary angioedema (HAE), like ACE-I related angioedema, the use of anti- histamines, corticosteroids and epinephrine offer no benefit. Some patients with HAE are prescribed medication which may reverse it. Paramedics may assist the patient with or ad- minister these medication per patient or packaging/prescription instructions.

02.05A.title: Altered Mental Status - Adult
02.05A.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with reduced mental status compared with baseline.
• Routine patient care.
• Perform blood glucose (bG) analysis. If the bG is ≤ 60 mg/dl or ≥ 250 mg/dl or signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia are present in the absence of the ability to perform bG analysis, treat patient per the Diabetic Emergencies Protocol.
• Obtain history and perform initial assessment to include mental status, neurologic, head, ears, eyes, nose, throat (HEENT), skin, lungs, cardiac, abdomen, back, extremities.
• Exit to appropriate protocol as indicated based on history and assessment findings: Suggestive Findings Protocol Miosis, hypoventilation/apnea, needle track Toxicological Emergencies marks, other toxidrome findings
Acetone odor on breath, rapid respiratory rate Diabetic Emergencies Hypotension or signs of poor perfusion General Shock and Hypotension
Evidence of trauma, unequal pupils Head Trauma - Traumatic Brain Injury Hypothermia and Hypothermia Localized Cold Injury
E Heat related illness Heat Related Illness

02.05P.title: Altered Mental Status - Pediatric
02.05P.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with reduced mental status compared with baseline.
• Routine patient care.
• Perform blood glucose (bG) analysis. If the bG is ≤ 60 mg/dl or ≥ 250 mg/dl or signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia are present in the absence of the ability to perform bG analysis, treat patient per the Diabetic Emergencies Protocol.
• Obtain history and perform initial assessment to include mental status, neurologic, head, ears, eyes, nose, throat (HEENT), skin, lungs, cardiac, abdomen, back, extremities.
• Exit to appropriate protocol as indicated based on history and assessment
findings:
Suggestive Findings Protocol Miosis, hypoventilation/apnea, needle track Toxicological Emergencies marks, other toxidrome findings
Acetone odor on breath, rapid respiratory rate Diabetic Emergencies Hypotension or signs of poor perfusion General Shock and Hypotension
Evidence of trauma, unequal pupils Head Trauma - Traumatic Brain Injury Hypothermia Hypothermia and Localized Cold Injury

02.06P.title: Brief Resolved Unexplained Event
02.06P.content:
Recognition:
• An event occurring in an infant < 1 y.o. when the observer reports a sudden, brief (< 1 mi-
nute), and now resolved episode of ≥ 1 of the following:
• Cyanosis or pallor
• Absent, decreased or irregular breathing
• Marked change in tone (hyper or hypotonia)
• Altered level of responsiveness
• Routine patient care.
• Perform blood glucose analysis and manage per the Diabetic Emergencies Protocol.
• Obtain history of event with particular attention to:
Activity at onset and history of the event
○ ) State during the event (cyanosis, apnea, coughing, gagging, vomiting)
End of the event (duration, gradual or abrupt cessation, treatment provided) State after the event (normal, not normal)
○ Recent history (illness, injuries, sick contacts, use of OTC medications, recent ( immunizations, new or different formula).
Past medical history (gestational age, pre-/perinatal history, GERD, seizures,
○ previous BRUE). Family history (sudden unexplained deaths, prolonged QT interval, arrhythmias). Medications in the residence Sleeping position/parent co-sleeping.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
NOTES:
• BRUE was formerly known as Apparent Life Threatening Event (ALTE).
• BRUE is formally diagnosed (in the ED) only when there is no explanation for a qualifying event after conducting an appropriate history and physical examination.
• Recommended exam: general appearance, vital signs (including temperature), cardiac, pulmonary, skin, neurologic.
• BRUE is not a disease, but a symptom. Common etiologies include central apnea (immature respiratory center), obstructive apnea (structural), GERD (laryngospasm, choking, gagging), respiratory (pertussis, RSV), cardiac (CHD, arrhythmia), seizures.
• Always consider non-accidental trauma in any infant who presents with BRUE.
• Even with a normal physical examination at the time of EMS contact, patients that have experienced BRUE should be transported for further evaluation and work-up.
• It is important to note sleeping position as parent co-sleeping with child is associated with infant death.

02.07A.title: Patient Comfort - Adult
02.07A.content:
Recognition
• This protocol applies to adult patients with pain or nausea and/or vomiting.
• This protocol is generally to be entered from a complaint specific protocol.
• Assess pain severity utilizing a pain scale, circumstances, mechanism of injury, and severity of illness or injury.
• For mild to moderate pain (scale of 1-6), consider: IBUPROFEN 10 mg/kg (typical adult 400-800 mg) PO or,
ACETAMINOPHEN 15 mg/kg (typical adult 500-1000 mg) PO or,
ASPIRIN 324-650 mg PO.
• For moderate to severe pain (scale >6), consider: Interventions as above for mild pain.
E If available, inhaled NITRONOX (50/50 nitrous oxide and oxygen blend).
• Monitor, reassess and document response to treatment.
ti
• For patients with nausea or vomiting, ONDANSETRON 4 mg PO/SL/IV/IM/ODT (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes).
• For mild to moderate pain (scale of 1-6), as an alternative to ACETAMINOPHEN above, consider ACETAMINOPHEN 500-1000 mg IV.
• For severe pain (scale >6), FENTANYL 0.5-1 mcg/kg IV/IM/IN [maximum single dose 50 mcg] (may repeat every 10 minutes to a maximum of 200 mcg). IV dose should be given over 2 minutes.
• For patients with nausea or vomiting, ONDANSETRON 4 mg PO/SL/IV/IM/ODT (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes).
• For patients requiring sedation for electrical therapy (cardioversion or pacing),
C consider MIDAZOLAM 2.5-5 mg IV/IM/IN or DIAZEPAM 2.5-5 mg IV/IM (must have continuous quantitative waveform capnography in place).
• Monitor and reassess response to treatment and vital signs prior to and 5 minutes following any dose of narcotic analgesic and before transfer of care (patient hand off). This must be documented in the PCR.
• For mild to moderate pain (scale of 1-6) consider KETOROLAC 15 MG IV or 30 mg IM or, as an alternative to ACETAMINOPHEN above, consider ACETAMINOPHEN 500- 1000 mg IV.
• For severe pain (scale >6): FENTANYL 0.5-1 mcg/kg IV/IM/IN [maximum single dose 50 mcg] (may repeat every 10 minutes to a maximum of 200 mcg). IV doses should be given over minutes, or For patients with traumatic pain or burns, KETAMINE 0.1 to 0.25 mg/kg IV (may repeat x1 q 10 minutes) or 0.25 to 0.5 mg/kg IM/IN (may repeat x1 q 30 minutes).
• For patients with nausea or vomiting: ONDANSETRON 4 mg PO/SL/IV/IM/ODT (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes). For patients requiring sedation for electrical therapy (cardioversion or pacing) or other procedure requiring sedation, consider MIDAZOLAM 2.5-5mg IV/IM/IN or LORAZEPAM 1-2mg IV/IM or DIAZEPAM 2.5-5 mg IV/IM or KETAMINE 0.5-1 mg/kg IV or KETAMINE 2mg/kg IM (must have continuous quantitative waveform capnography in place).
• For patients with an advanced airway in place (BIAD/ETI/cricothyrotomy) requiring
sedation and analgesia, consider:
MIDAZOLAM 2.5-5 mg IV every 5-10 minutes as needed (maximum dose 10mg) or LORAZEPAM 1-2 mg IV every 15 minutes as needed (maximum 10mg) and FENTANYL 1.0-1.5 mcg/kg slow IV push (maximum 100mcg per dose, may repeat in 10 minutes to a total of 200mcg. Contact Medical Control for additional doses).
• For patients with an advanced airway in place (ETI/BIAD/cricothyrotomy) if necessary for patient safety or to facilitate ventilation, consider ROCURONIUM 1 mg/kg IV or ti VECURONIUM 0.1 mg/kg IV (must have continuous quantitative waveform capnography in place and must be preceded by sedation as above).
• Monitor and reassess response to treatment and vital signs prior to and 5 minutes following any dose of narcotic analgesic and before transfer of care (patient hand off). This must be documented in the PCR.
NOTES:
• DO NOT administer ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil) or ketorolac (Toradol) to patients who are pregnant, have a history of renal failure or transplant, are allergic to non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agents (NSAIDs), have active bleeding (including GI bleeding), have suspected intracranial hemorrhage, or in patients that may require surgical intervention such as those with open fractures/fractures with deformity.
• DO NOT administer aspirin to patients that have active bleeding (including GI bleeding, suspected intracranial hemorrhage, or in patients that may require surgical intervention such as those with open fractures/ fractures with deformity).
• PO analgesics are not indicated for abdominal pain.
• DO NOT administer PO medications to patients who may require surgical intervention.
• Individual patients may respond differently to opioid analgesics. The patient’s age, weight, clinical condition, co-administered/ingested drugs (alcohol, benzodiazepines) and prior exposure to opiates should all be considered when determining the dose to be administered. Weight based dosing provides a standard means for dose calculation, but does not predict patient response. Example: minimal doses of opioids may cause respiratory depression in geriatric, opiate naïve or alcohol intoxicated patients. It is much safer to administer a low opioid dose and repeat as necessary than to administer a high dose initially.
• Avoid co-administering multiple sedating agents in non-intubated patients due to the risk for respiratory depression.
• Consider the use of waveform capnography in all patients receiving narcotic analgesics or ketamine.
• Patients with alcohol intoxication or those that have received benzodiazepines are at e ti increased risk for respiratory depression following the administration of narcotic analgesics.
• Sub-anesthetic (low) dose ketamine has demonstrated significant analgesic efficacy without the adverse effects associated with higher doses. While uncommon, ketamine administration may result in laryngeal spasm and/or increased salivation. Laryngeal spasm is transient and can be managed with positive pressure ventilation if need be.
• As the dose related effect of ketamine transitions from analgesia to anesthesia, t nystagmus emerges and as such, ketamine administration should be discontinued when nystagmus occurs.
• Ketamine should be administered over 60 seconds when given IV.
• Ketamine should not be used in patients with penetrating ocular injuries or known . coronary artery disease.
• Droperidol has a sedating effect. Document mental status and vital signs prior to administration.
• Advanced airway placement MUST be confirmed by the presence of waveform capnography (> 6 breaths) prior to the administration of rocuronium or vecuronium and documented continuous airway monitoring with waveform capnography is required.
• For IM administration, the 100 mg/ml concentration of ketamine is preferred.
• Ketamine in a concentration of 100 mg/ml must be diluted 1:1 with 0.9% saline, D W or sterile water creating a 50 mg/ml concentration prior to IV use.

02.07P.title: Patient Comfort - Pediatric
02.07P.content:
Recognition
• This protocol applies to pediatric patients with pain, nausea or vomiting.
• This protocol is generally to be entered from a complaint specific protocol.
• Assess pain severity utilizing age appropriate pain scale (numeric, Wong-Baker faces or FLACC scale), circumstances, mechanism of injury, and severity of illness or injury.
• For mild to moderate pain (scale of 1-6), consider: IBUPROFEN 10 mg/kg (800 mg maximum) PO or
ACETAMINOPHEN 15 mg/kg (1000 mg maximum) PO.
• For severe pain (scale >6), consider: Interventions as above for mild pain.
E ⃝ If available, inhaled NITRONOX (50/50 nitrous oxide and oxygen blend).
• Monitor, reassess and document response to treatment.
ti
• For patients with nausea or vomiting, ONDANSETRON 0.2 mg/kg (maximum dose mg) PO/SL/IV/IM/ODT (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes). Do not use in patients <3 months old.
• For mild to moderate pain (scale of 1-6), as an alternative to ACETAMINOPHEN above, consider ACETAMINOPHEN 15 mg/kg IV (1000 mg maximum single dose).
• For severe pain (scale >6), FENTANYL 0.5-1 mcg/kg IV/IM/IN [maximum single dose 50 mcg] (may repeat every 10 minutes to a maximum cumulative dose of 150 mcg). . IV doses should be given over 2 minutes.
• For patients with nausea or vomiting, ONDANSETRON 0.2 mg/kg (maximum dose mg) PO/SL/IV/IM/ODT (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes). Do not use in patients <3 months old.
• For patients requiring sedation for electrical therapy (cardioversion or pacing), consider MIDAZOLAM 0.1 mg/kg [2.5 mg maximum] IV/IM/IN or FENTANYL 2 mcg/ kg [50 mcg maximum] IV/IM/IN (must have continuous quantitative waveform capnography in place).
• Monitor and reassess response to treatment and vital signs prior to and 5 minutes following any dose of narcotic analgesic and before transfer of care (patient hand off). This must be documented in the PCR.
• For minor to moderate pain (scale of 1-6), consider KETOROLAC 0.5 mg/kg IV/IM (maximum 30 mg) or, as an alternative to ACETAMINOPHEN above, consider
ACETAMINOPHEN 15 mg/kg IV (1000 mg maximum single dose).
• For severe pain (scale >6): FENTANYL 0.5-1 mcg/kg IV/IM/IN [maximum single dose 50mcg] (may repeat every 10 minutes to a maximum cumulative dose of 150 mcg). IV doses should be given over 2 minutes or For patients with traumatic pain or burns, KETAMINE 0.1 mg/kg IV or 0.2 mg/kg IM/IN. IV dosing may be repeated every 10 minutes and IM/IN doses may be repeated once in 30 minutes as needed to a maximum cumulative dose of mg.
• For patients with nausea or vomiting, ONDANSETRON 0.2 mg/kg (maximum dose mg) PO/SL/IV/IM/ODT (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes). Do not use in patients <3 months old.
• For patients requiring sedation for electrical therapy (cardioversion or pacing) or other procedure requiring sedation, consider MIDAZOLAM 0.1 mg/kg [2.5 mg maximum] IV/IM/IN or FENTANYL 2 mcg/kg [50mcg maximum] IV/IM/IN or r KETAMINE 0.5-1 mg/kg IV or KETAMINE 2 mg/kg IM (must have continuous f quantitative waveform capnography in place).
• For patients with an advanced airway in place (ETI/BIAD/cricothyrotomy) requiring sedation, consider FENTANYL 1.5-3.0 mcg/kg IV (maximum 50mcg per dose, may repeat in 10 minutes to a total of 100mcg. Contact Medical Control for additional ti doses).
• Monitor and reassess response to treatment and vital signs prior to and 5 minutes following any dose of narcotic analgesic and before transfer of care (patient hand off). This must be documented in the PCR.
NOTES:
• Use extreme caution in administering opioids to patients < 10 kg.
• DO NOT administer Ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil) and ketorolac (Toradol) to patients who are pregnant, have a history of renal failure or transplant, are allergic to non-steroidal anti- inflammatory agents (NSAIDs), have active bleeding (including GI bleeding), have suspected intracranial hemorrhage, or in patients who may require surgical intervention such as those with open fractures/fractures with deformity.
• DO NOT administer aspirin to patients that have active bleeding, including GI bleeding, have suspected intracranial hemorrhage, or in patients who may require surgical intervention such as those with open fractures / fractures with deformity.
• DO NOT administer PO medications to patients who may require surgical intervention.
• PO analgesics are not indicated for abdominal pain.
• Individual patients may respond differently to opioid analgesics. The patient’s age, weight, clinical condition, co-administered/ingested drugs (alcohol, benzodiazepines) and prior exposure to opiates should all be considered when determining the dose to be administered. Weight based dosing provides a standard means for dose calculation, but does not predict patient response. Example: minimal doses of opioids may cause respiratory depression in elderly, opiate naïve or alcohol intoxicated patients.
• Avoid co-administering multiple sedating agents in non-intubated patients due to the risk for respiratory depression.
• Consider the use of waveform capnography in all patients receiving narcotic analgesics or ti ketamine.
• Patients with alcohol intoxication or those who have received benzodiazepines are at increased risk for respiratory depression following the administration of narcotic analgesics.
• For pediatric administration, the 10 mg/ml concentration of ketamine is to be used.
• Sub-anesthetic (low) dose ketamine has demonstrated significant analgesic efficacy without the adverse effects associated with higher doses. While uncommon, ketamine administration may result in laryngeal spasm and/or increased salivation. Laryngeal spasm is transient and can be managed with positive pressure ventilation if need be.
• As the dose related effect of ketamine transitions from analgesia to anesthesia, nystagmus emerges and as such, ketamine administration should be discontinued when nystagmus occurs. r
• Ketamine should not be used in patients with penetrating ocular injuries or known coronary artery disease.
• Vomiting without diarrhea in pediatric patients may be related to pyloric stenosis, bowel obstruction or a CNS process (bleed, tumor, increased ICP).
• Utilize age appropriate pain scoring systems (see next page). For most patients > 9 yo, . the numeric (1-10) scale is appropriate. For patients 2 months-7 years, the FLACC scale may be used. The Wong-Baker-Faces scale may be used for patients > 3 y.o.
• Advanced airway placement MUST be confirmed by the presence of a waveform capnography (> 6 breaths) prior to the administration of rocuronium or vecuronium. continuous airway monitoring with waveform capnography is required. FLACC Scale Scoring t
