• Ejection (partial or complete) from vehicle or
• Death of occupant in same compartment.
• Auto vs. pedestrian/bicyclist thrown, run over, or with significant (>20 mph) impact
• Motorcycle crash > 20 mph Special Patient or System Considerations
• Patient taking anticoagulants/antiplatelet agents (excluding ASA) or with bleeding disorder
• EMS healthcare professional’s judgment

04.02.title: Head Trauma - Traumatic Brain Injury
04.02.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with a history or clinical evidence of blunt or penetrating head trauma.
• Patient with anticoagulant/antiplatelet medication with trauma (even without direct head strike).
• Routine patient care.
• Obtain baseline neurologic examination (GCS, pupils, motor). If the patient has clinical evidence of increased intracranial pressure, manage per the Acute Neurologic Event with Evidence of Increased ICP Protocol.
• Provide airway management as indicated per age appropriate Airway Management )
Protocol.
• Ventilate the patient as indicated to maintain the EtCO 2 35-45 mmHg (avoid ( hyperventilation), if capnography is not available, ventilate the patient at a rate of 8-10 bpm.
E • If the patient has altered mental status, perform blood glucose analysis and manage per the age appropriate Diabetic Emergencies Protocol.
• Transport to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. Patients with i evidence of TBI (altered mental status, significant wound, etc.) should be transported to a Level I Trauma Center.
ti
• Manage hypotension per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension
Protocol.
-
NOTES:
• Patients taking anticoagulant/antiplatelet agents with altered mental status following trauma should be transported to an age appropriate Level I Trauma Center.
• Access and document the patient’s neurologic examination. Convey the patient’s best neuro- logic examination and any episodes of hypoxia or hypotension during patient hand off.
• Hypotension is usually a terminal event in isolated head trauma. If hypotension is present, the etiology should be aggressively identified and treated.
• Serial examination of the patient’s mental status should be conducted and documented.
• Attempt to obtain information related to use of antiplatelet or anticoagulants by the patient.
• Brain ischemia is worsened by hyperventilation. Patients with head injury should be ventilated to maintain normocapnia (EtCO 35-45 mmHg), unless there is evidence of worsening mental status/increasing ICP.
• Even short isolated episodes of hypoxia or hypotension should be avoided as they can cause secondary brain injury.
• Hyperglycemia is associated with worsened neurologic outcome. Glucose containing solutions should be administered only as indicated for the treatment of hypoglycemia.

04.03.title: Spinal Precautions
04.03.content:
Recognition:
• Patient experiencing a mechanism of injury with risk for spinal injury or symptoms concerning for spinal cord injury such as radiating pain, numbness, or weakness, with or without trauma.
Trauma patients meeting any of the following criteria require spinal precautions:
• Patients aged <3 yo or >65 yo.
• Altered mental status (includes dementia, psychosis, pre-existing brain injury, developmental delay).
• Suspected intoxication (alcohol or other substance).
• Insurmountable communication barrier.
• Presence of a distracting injury (an injury believed to be producing pain sufficient to distract the patient from a second (neck/spine injury).
• History of underlying spinal disease, surgery (includes fusion or hardware implant) or malignancy with potential for bone metastasis.
• Motor vehicle crash >60 mph or with rollover or ejection.
• Falls >3ft/5 stairs (fall from 3ft above ground surface).
• Axial load to head/neck (diving, contact sport collision, heavy weighted object falling on head).
• Significant injury or MOI above clavicles.
• Injuries involving motorized recreational vehicles (ATV, snowmobile, etc.).
• Bicycle collision/struck.
ti For patients not meeting any of the above criteria, or with symptoms concerning for
spinal pathology without trauma, assess as below:
• Apply a rigid cervical collar (for patients who poorly tolerate a rigid cervical collar [e.g. anxiety, shortness of breath], the collar may be replaced with an alternative such as soft padding, towels and/or other padding to restrict movement).
• Patients without any of the concerns listed above may “self-extricate” themselves from a vehicle.
• Ambulatory, alert, and cooperative patients may be allowed to sit and then lie flat on the ambulance stretcher.
• Pull sheets, other flexible devices, scoop and scoop-like stretchers, or vacuum mattresses should be used to move non-ambulatory patients.
• Long spine boards (LSB) should be used for extrication and patient movement purposes only. If a LSB is used, once the patient is moved onto the ambulance stretcher, the LSB should be removed by using a log roll or lift and slide technique.
Patients should only be transported on a LSB if it is necessary for patient safety (e.g., combative patient), if removal from the LSB would delay transportation of an unstable patient or if it is necessary for other treatment priorities (management of increased intracranial pressure).
• Vacuum mattress or scoop stretcher devices should be used for patients who require spinal precautions during transport.
• Patients should be placed supine on the ambulance stretcher, securely restrained utilizing stretcher straps and instructed to minimize moving their head or neck as s much as possible. Elevate the head of the stretcher only if necessary to support ti respiratory function, patient compliance, or other treatment priorities.
• Patients with nausea or vomiting may be placed in a lateral recumbent position while maintaining their head in a neutral position using manual stabilization, padding/pillows or the patient’s arm. These patients should also be provided antiemetic therapy per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
E • Consider using SpO and EtCO to monitor respiratory function.
• Transfer from am bulance to hospital stretchers and vise-versa should be accomplished while continuing to limit motion of the spine. Slide boards or sheet lifts etc. should be used.
• Patients with penetrating trauma such as gunshot or stab wounds do not require SMRP unless a neurologic deficit is noted.
For pediatric patients ≤6 yo or ≤27 kg (60 lbs.) requiring spinal precautions:
• Transport the patient in a pediatric restraint system as described in the Routine
Patient Care Protocol. Use pediatric restraint systems for older/larger children when appropriate when they fall within the device’s recommended range.
• Apply padding and a cervical collar as tolerated to minimize spinal motion. Do . not force application of a cervical collar if it is not tolerated by the patient. Rolled towels should be used if a cervical collar is not tolerated.
• Avoid any movements that provoke increased spinal movement.
• If the patient requires significant care (e.g., airway management) that cannot be accomplished in the car seat or pediatric restraint system, remove the patient and secure them directly to the stretcher.
• Patients involved in a motor vehicle crash (MVC) may remain in their own child
safety seat for transport, provided all of the following criteria are met:
1. The seat has a self-contained harness;
2. The seat is convertible with both front and rear belt paths;
3. Inspection does not reveal cracks or deformation;
4. Vehicle in which the seat was installed was capable of being driven from the scene of the crash;
5. Vehicle door nearest the child safety seat was undamaged;
6. There was no airbag deployment; and
7. The EMS healthcare professional is able to ensure appropriate assessment of the patient’s posterior.
8. The safety seat is appropriately secured to the ambulance stretcher, airway seat or bench.
ti
NOTES:
• Examples of distracting injuries include long bone fractures, visceral injuries, joint dislocations, crush injuries, large burns and thoracic trauma.
• In some circumstances, extrication of a patient utilizing traditional spinal immobilization techniques may result in greater spinal movement or may dangerously delay extrication.

04.04.title: External Hemorrhage Control
04.04.content:
Recognition:
• Patient exhibiting external hemorrhaging.
• Routine patient care.
• Apply direct pressure/pressure dressing to the injury (including use of mechanical pressure dressing .
• If direct pressure is ineffective: If the wound is amenable to tourniquet placement (e.g., extremity injury), apply a hemostatic tourniquet. If the wound is not amenable to tourniquet placement apply a hemostatic agent dressing, if available, with direct pressure. For junctional hemorrhage, if available consider use of a junctional tourniquet and/or an expandable, multi-sponged dressing.
• For hemorrhage originating from a dialysis shunt/fistula:
Apply firm finger tip pressure to the bleeding site.
Apply a pressure dressing (avoid bulky dressing, dressings which tend to absorb blood but not control hemorrhage.
If direct pressure and pressure dressing are not effective, apply a tourniquet to
○ the affected extremity. The tourniquet should be applied proximally as remote from the location of the shunt/fistula as possible.
• Manage per the age appropriate Hemorrhagic Shock Protocol as indicated.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
NOTES:
• EMS healthcare professionals should use tourniquets for severe hemorrhage not easily controlled with direct pressure.
• Tourniquets properly applied for hemostatic control should both stop bleeding and eliminate the distal pulse.
• Remember to reassess for bleeding after tourniquet application throughout the course of resuscitation.
• Some injuries may require the application of more than one tourniquet.
• Once applied, do NOT loosen or remove tourniquets in the field.
• If available, a pneumatic anti-shock garment (PASG) may be useful to tamponade bleeding associated with groin/lower extremity junctional wounds, blast injuries, and bilateral, if available.

04.05.title: Extremity and Musculoskeletal Injuries
04.05.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with an extremity or musculoskeletal injury/complaint.
• Routine patient care.
• Manage as indicated per the age appropriate protocols: Wound Care Procedure
External Hemorrhage Control Hemorrhagic Shock
Patient Comfort
• Remove rings, bracelets or other constricting items.
• For amputations, clean amputated part, wrap in saline soaked sterile dressing, and place in airtight container. If ice is available, place container on ice (there should be no direct contact between tissue and the ice).
• Immobilize injured extremities utilizing a padded board, wire ladder, vacuum, pillow, plaster/fiberglass or other commercially available splint as appropriate for the specific injury.
• Splint application should result in immobilization of the joint above and below a
E suspected fracture.
• For isolated mid-shaft femoral fractures, the use of a traction splint is the preferred technique for immobilization. A traction splint should not be utilized if a pelvic fracture is suspected.
• Distal peripheral neurovascular status should be assessed and documented in all patients with an extremity injury (this includes prior to and after immobilization).
• Suspected dislocations and angulated fractures should generally be immobilized in the position found. However, in some instances when transport time may be prolonged, gentle manipulation may be appropriate to restore distal circulation.
• Suspected pelvic fractures should be stabilized utilizing a pelvic binder.
• Cold packs may be applied to affected areas (avoid direct contact with skin).
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. i
P • For open fractures, amputations or grossly contaminated wounds, CEFTRIAXONE gm IV slow push over 5 minutes, must be a large bore IV. Pediatrics 50 mg/kg to maximum of 2 gm.
*See NOTES for additional information regarding ceftriaxone administration. .
NOTES:
• Intravenous infusion of ceftriaxone, over 30 minutes is the preferred administration route. However, if the paramedic is able to obtain intravenous access in a large vessel using large bore IV, a slow intravenous injection over 5 minutes is acceptable.
• Hip dislocations, elbow and knee dislocations and fractures have a high incidence of vascular injury.
• Blood loss may be concealed or not apparent with extremity injuries.
• Ceftriaxone should not be administered to patients with a history of allergy to ceftriaxone or related medications, or a severe (past anaphylactic reaction) to penicillin.

04.06.title: Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
04.06.content:
Recognition:
• Patient in cardiopulmonary arrest with presumed traumatic etiology.
• Routine patient care.
• Initiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) following the current AHA ECC Guidelines while implementing Spinal Precautions if indicated.
• Consider a possible medical etiology for arrest if a direct mechanism is not clear (e.g., operator of motor vehicle with minor to moderate vehicular damage observed to suddenly “swerve off the road” prior to collision and now found in cardiac arrest). If uncertainty exists regarding medical or traumatic etiology for cardiac arrest, manage per age appropriate medical Cardiac Arrest Protocol.
• Control external hemorrhage following the External Hemorrhage Control Protocol.
• Manage other potentially life threatening injuries as per appropriate protocols.
E • For patients with a suspected pelvic fracture or those with a mechanism with high risk for pelvic fracture (pedestrian struck), apply a pelvic binder following the
Pelvic Binder Application Procedure Protocol.
• Rapidly initiate transportation. If the transport to the nearest Level 1 Trauma Center is <15 minutes, transport to the nearest Level 1 Trauma Center. If the transport time is >15 minutes, transport to the nearest Hospital Emergency Facility.
ti
A • Establish IV access
• LACTATED RINGER’S 1L IV bolus [20 ml/kg for pediatrics] (may repeat x1).
• Establish IV access
• LACTATED RINGER’S 1L IV bolus [20 ml/kg for pediatrics] (may repeat x1). .
P • Perform needle thoracostomy for suspected tension pneumothorax or in any patient in cardiac arrest with chest trauma.
NOTES:
• Consider a medical etiology if uncertainty exists regarding etiology for cardiac arrest.
• If the use of spinal motion restriction precautions interferes with the performance of high quality CPR, make reasonable efforts to manually limit patient movement.

04.07A.title: Thermal Burn Injury - Adult
04.07A.content:
Recognition:
• Minor Burn: < 5% total body surface area (TBSA) partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, no inhalation injury, not intubated, normotensive, GCS 14 or greater.
• Serious Burn: 5-15% TBSA partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, suspected inhalation injury or requiring advanced airway management for airway stabilization, hypotension or GCS < 13.
• Critical Burn: > 15% TBSA partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, burns with airway compromise, burns with multiple trauma. Burns involving the face, hands, genitalia, perineum or major joints also meet criteria for a critical burn.
• Routine patient care.
• Assess Burn/Concomitant Injury Severity and utilize the Rule of Nines (see next page) to estimate body surface area (TBSA) affected and assess for evidence of traumatic injuries.
• For minor burns: Stop the burning process and remove smoldering and non-adherent clothing. Remove rings, bracelets and other constricting items.
Apply dry clean sterile sheet or dressing.
Manage as per age appropriate trauma related protocols as indicated.
Monitor carboxyhemoglobin (SpCO) if available. If carbon monoxide (CO) or
E cyanide exposure is suspected, manage per the Carbon Monoxide Exposure r
Protocol. If SpCO is unavailable and CO poisoning is suspected, administer 100% j oxygen.
○ Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. r
Analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• For serious or critical burns: l Manage as above.
○ Transport the patient to the nearest Accredited Adult Burn Center. If the patient r meets clinical criteria for transportation to a Level 1 Trauma Center, they should be transported to the nearest Level 1 Adult Trauma Center/Burn Center as appropriate for their clinical condition unless authorized by MEDICAL CONTROL.
• For minor burns:
Analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
Establish IV access if indicated. l
• For serious or critical burns:
Establish IV access, consider two IV sites if greater than 15% TBSA is affected.
C ⃝
○ LACTATED RINGER’S at 300 ml/hr. If the patient is hypotensive or there is evidence of shock, administer a 1000 ml bolus of LACTATED RINGER’S, repeat as . needed if hypotension or evidence of shock persists.
• For minor burns:
Analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
IV access if indicated.
• For serious or critical burns: IV access, consider two IV sites if greater than 15% TBSA is affected. LACTATED RINGER’S at 300 ml/hr. If the patient is hypotensive or there is
P ⃝ evidence of shock, administer a 1000ml bolus of LACTATED RINGER’S, repeat as needed if hypotension or evidence of shock persists.
Consider early intubation for patients with respiratory distress due to evolving airway obstruction secondary airway edema.
For burns >20% TBSA with a definitive airway (i.e., ETT in place), consider placement of a gastric tube.
*Only areas affected by partial thickness and full thickness burns are used in calculating affected TBSA.
NOTES:
• Recommended exam: mental status, airway, HEENT, neck, heart, lungs, abdomen, extremities, back, and neurologic.
• Deviation from transporting a serious or critical burn patient to an accredited burn center is permissible if critical interventions such as airway management are indicated, but not possible in the field.
• Patients with thermal burn injuries often have non-burn related traumatic injuries, evaluate for multisystem trauma.
• Burn patients are prone to hypothermia, maintain normothermia.
• Burn patients should NOT receive intramuscular (IM) injections.

04.07P.title: Thermal Burn Injury - Pediatric
04.07P.content:
Recognition:
• Minor Burn: < 5% total body surface area (TBSA) partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, no inhalation injury, not intubated, normotensive, GCS 14 or greater.
• Serious Burn: 5-15% TBSA partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, suspected inhalation injury or requiring advanced airway management for airway stabilization, hypotension or GCS < 13.
• Critical Burn: > 15% TBSA partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, burns with airway compromise, burns with multiple trauma. Burns involving the face, hands, genitalia perineum or major joints also meet criteria for a critical burn.
• Routine patient care.
• Assess Burn/Concomitant Injury Severity and utilize the pediatric Rule of Nines (see next page) to estimate body surface area (TBSA) affected and assess for evidence of traumatic injuries.
• For minor burns: Stop the burning process and remove smoldering and non-adherent clothing. Remove rings, bracelets and other constricting items. Stop the burning process and remove smoldering and non-adherent clothing.
Apply dry clean sterile sheet or dressing.
Manage as per age appropriate trauma related protocols as indicated.
Monitor carboxyhemoglobin (SpCO) if available. If carbon monoxide or cyanide
E exposure is suspected, also manage per the Carbon Monoxide Exposure
Protocol. If SpCO is unavailable and carbon monoxide poisoning is suspected administer 100% oxygen Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Facility Emergency Department.
Analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• For serious or critical burns: Manage as above. Transport the patient to the nearest Accredited Pediatric Burn Center. If the patient meets clinical criteria for transportation to a Level I Trauma Center, they should be transported to the nearest Level I Pediatric Trauma Center/Burn
Center as appropriate for their clinical condition unless authorized by MEDICAL
CONTROL.
A • For minor burns: i
Establish IV access if indicated.
Analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• For serious or critical burns:
Establish IV access, consider two IV sites if greater than 15% TBSA affected. .
C ⃝ LACTATED RINGER’S at 20 ml/kg/hr. If the patient is hypotensive or there is evidence of shock, administer a 20 ml/kg IVF bolus, repeat as needed if hypotension or evidence of shock persists.
Provide analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• For minor burns:
Establish IV access if indicated.
Analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• For serious or critical burns:
Establish IV access, consider two IV sites if greater than 15% TBSA is affected.
P LACTATED RINGER’S at 20 ml/kg/hr. If the patient is hypotensive or there is evidence of shock, administer a 20 ml/kg IVF bolus, repeat as needed if hypotension or evidence of shock persists.
Early intubation for patients with respiratory distress due to evolving airway obstruction secondary airway edema.
For burns >20% BSA with a definitive airway (i.e., ETT in place), consider placement of a gastric tube.
Only areas affected by partial thickness and full thickness burns are used in calculating affected TBSA.
NOTES: i
• Recommended exam: mental status, airway, HEENT, neck, heart, lungs, abdomen, extrem- ities, back, and neurologic.
• Superficial (1st degree) burns are characterized by pain and redness, partial thickness (second degree) are characterized by pain and blistering, full thickness (3rd degree) burns . are characterized by painlessness and white/brown coloration.
• Evaluate for the possibility of child abuse in all pediatric patients with burn injuries.
• Deviation from transporting a serious or critical burn patient to an accredited pediatric burn center is permissible if critical interventions such as airway management are indicat- ed, but not possible in the field.
• Patients with thermal burn injuries often have non-burn related traumatic injuries, evalu- ate for multisystem trauma.
• Burn patients are prone to hypothermia, maintain normothermia.
• Burn patients should NOT receive intramuscular (IM) injections.

04.08.title: Chemical and Electrical Burn Injury
04.08.content:
Recognition:
• Partial or full thickness burn injury resulting from contact with a chemical agent or energized electrical source.
• Minor burn: < 5% total body surface area (TBSA) partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, no inhalation injury, not intubated, normotensive, GCS 14 or greater.
• Serious burn: 5-15% TBSA partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, suspected inhalation injury or requiring advanced airway management for airway stabilization, hypotension, GCS < 13, circumferential burns of the extremities.
• Critical burn: > 15% TBSA partial (2nd degree) and full thickness (3rd degree) burns, burns with airway compromise, burns with multiple trauma. Burns involving the face, hands, genitalia, perineum or major joints also meet criteria for a critical burn.
• Ensure chemical source is not hazardous to EMS healthcare professionals or other responders. Seek hazardous materials resources as indicated. r
• Ensure that the electrical source is no longer a hazard, e.g., not in contact with the j patient prior to touching the patient, not a scene risk.
• Routine patient care.
• Initiate decontamination by removing contaminated clothing. Maintain patient privacy.
• Assess burn/concomitant injury severity and utilize the Rule of Nines (see age appropriate Thermal Burn Injury Protocol) to estimate total body surface area (TBSA) i affected and assess for evidence of traumatic injuries.
• Decontaminate liquid chemical burns by irrigating the affected areas with NORMAL SALINE (clean water or other appropriate solutions or decontaminants may be used as appropriate) for 15 minutes, repeat as needed.
• For exposure to powdered chemicals, the affected contact points should be brushed off and then irrigated as above. l
E • For exposure to hydrofluoric acid (HF), apply, if available, CALCIUM GLUCONATE 2.5 topical gel to all contact points. If the hands or digits are involved, the gel should be placed in an exam glove and the glove worn on the affected hand. If there is ocular exposure, irrigate the affected eye with, if available, CALCIUM GLUCONATE 1% solution.
• Remove non-adherent clothing, rings, bracelets and other constricting items.
• Manage per the age appropriate Thermal Burn Injury Protocol and trauma related protocols as indicated.
• Transport the patient to nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. Patients with serious or critical burns require transport nearest age appropriate Accredited
Adult Burn Center or Pediatric Burn Center. If the patient meets clinical criteria for transportation to a Level 1 Trauma Center, they should be transported to the nearest age appropriate Level 1 Trauma Center as appropriate for their clinical condition unless authorized by MEDICAL CONTROL.
• Initiate cardiac monitoring if indicated, manage per age appropriate Cardiac Arrest
Protocol and Cardiac Dysrhythmia Protocols as indicated.
• Initiate cardiac monitoring if indicated, manage per age appropriate Cardiac Arrest
Protocol and Cardiac Dysrhythmia Protocols as indicated.
• For patients with exposure to hydrofluoric acid (HF) with signs and symptoms of hypocalcemia, consider CALCIUM CHLORIDE 1gm slow IV push (may repeat x1). If inhalation injury is suspected, consider, if available, CALCIUM GLUCONATE 2.5% solution via SVN (see notes for mixture calculation).
NOTES:
• Recommended exam: mental status, airway, HEENT, neck, heart, lungs, abdomen, ex- tremities, back, neurologic.
• Normal saline or sterile water is preferred for irrigation purposes, however do not delay irrigation if only tap or other water is available. The area should be irrigated as soon as possible with normal saline or sterile water once available.
• Findings suggestive of hypocalcemia include tetany, perioral paresthesia, increased deep tendon reflexes, laryngospasm, prolonged QT/QTC or polymorphic VT.
• Calcium gluconate gel may be made by mixing 7.5ml of 10% calcium gluconate to 22.5ml of water soluble surgical lubricant.
• For electrical burns, attempt to determine the nature of the electrical source (AC/DC), voltage, etc.

04.09.title: Crush Injury
04.09.content:
Recognition:
• Extremity/body crush, entrapped and/or crushed under heavy load (e.g., structural or trench collapse, heavy equipment/machinery).
• Routine patient care.
• Request additional resources as needed.
• Implement the Major Incident Protocol if indicated.
• Stage until scene is safe/secure.
• Treat as indicated per age appropriate trauma protocols, General Shock and Hypotension Protocol or Hypothermia and Localized Cold Injury Protocol.
• Remove rings, bracelets or other constricting items.
• Request ALS response if available.
• Provide analgesia per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
A • Transport to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
• During extrication, consider D W (preferred) or NORMAL SALINE 1000 ml with 150 mEq of SODIUM BICARBONATE added at 1.5 L/hr (pediatrics 20 ml/kg x3). Once extricated ot the crush is resolved, reduce the infusion rate to 500 ml/hr (pediatrics run at age appropriate maintenance rate).
• An additional IV containing only crystalloid IV fluid should be used if volume resuscitation is required (i.e., hypotension is present) following the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension Protocol.
C • For patients with ECG changes suggestive of hyperkalemia or if the patient progresses to cardiac arrest, manage per the age appropriate Cardiac Arrest
Protocol and contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to administer CALCIUM
CHLORIDE 1gm IV or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 3 gm IV and SODIUM BICARBONATE
50 mEq IV.
• Consider ALBUTEROL 5 mg via SVN for patients with suspected hyperkalemia.
• During extrication, consider D W (preferred) or NORMAL SALINE 1,000 ml with 150 mEq of SODIUM BICARBONATE added at 1.5 L/hr (pediatrics 20 ml/kg x3). Once extricated or the crush is resolved, reduce the infusion rate to 500 ml/hr (pediatrics run at age appropriate maintenance rate).
• An additional IV containing only crystalloid IV fluid should be used if volume resuscitation is required (i.e., hypotension is present) following the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension Protocol.
P • For patients with ECG changes suggestive of hyperkalemia or if the patient progresses to cardiac arrest, manage per the age appropriate Cardiac Arrest Protocol and consider CALCIUM CHLORIDE 1 gm IV or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 3 gm IV and SODIUM BICARBONATE 50 mEq IV.
• Consider ALBUTEROL 5 mg via SVN for patients with suspected hyperkalemia. *see NOTES for additional information on sodium bicarbonate solution and mixture.
NOTES:
• Crush injury usually occurs with compression times of 4-6 hours, but may occur in ≤ minutes depending the force and mechanism causing tissue damage.
• Large volume hydration prior to extrication/removal of crush mechanism is critical to preventing acute kidney injury and mortality. Hydration should be initiated prior to extrication whenever possible
• The larger the area of crush injury (volume of tissue), the greater the likelihood of severe rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury.
• Patients with significant crush trauma can have significant fluid shifts (3rd spacing) > 12L in the first 48 hours.
• Sodium bicarbonate is preferentially mixed in D W (150 mEq/1000ml). Use of 0.9% saline for this purpose is less desirable, as that mixture is hypertonic.
• Monitor patient for signs/symptoms of compartment syndrome (pain, parlor, paresthesia, pulselessness).
• ECG findings suggestive of hyperkalemia include peaked T waves, QRS ≥ 0.12 sec, QT ≥
0.46 seconds or loss of P waves.
• Do not overlook other injuries, airway compromise, hypothermia or hyperthermia. Hypothermia may occur even in settings with warm ambient temperatures.
• Use EtCO (quantitative waveform capnography) if administering opioids and/or benzodiazepines.
• Confined space treatment should be performed only by appropriately trained personnel.
• If available, document air quality measurement at patient location on patient care j report.

04.10.title: Dental Trauma and Emergencies
04.10.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with tooth pain or dental injury, including facial edema originating from a dental source.
• Routine patient care.
• Evaluate dental or jaw pain for association with cardiac etiology. If cardiac etiology is suspected or cannot be ruled out, obtain multi-lead ECG and exit to age appropriate
Chest Pain - Acute Coronary Syndrome - STEMI Protocol.
• If dental injury is associated with significant or multisystem trauma, control bleeding with direct pressure and manage per the age appropriate trauma protocol.
• For dental related bleeding, control it with direct pressure by inserting a small gauze dressing rolled into a square and placed into tooth socket with patient closing teeth to exert pressure.
• For dental avulsions, place the avulsed tooth in whole milk, saline, or cell-cultured i medium. Do not rub or scrub the avulsed tooth.
• Provide analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• Transport patient to nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility if indicated. r
NOTES:
• Reimplantation of an avulsed tooth is possible within 4 hours if the tooth is properly cared for.
• Occasionally, pain of cardiac etiology may present as dental or jaw pain.
• All dental associated pain should be associated with a tooth which is tender to tapping, touch or heat/cold sensitivity.

04.11.title: Ocular Trauma and Emergencies
04.11.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with ocular complaint or injury.
• Routine patient care.
• When feasible, all patients with an ocular related complaint must have their visual acuity (Va) assessed and documented.
• Obtain history of contact lens use, corrective lenses, and safety goggles.
• Contact lenses should be removed when possible.
• For patients with penetrating ocular injuries, secure a rigid eye shield over the affected eye. Do not apply gauze type dressings directly over the affected eye as the dressing may adhere to ocular tissue and when it is removed may cause further extravasation of ocular contents. Cover/patch unaffected eye to reduce eye movement. If feasible, elevate the head of bed (HOB) to 30 degrees to decrease intraocular pressure.
• For patients with ocular impaled objects, immobilize the object and patch both eyes as above to reduce eye movement (any device used to immobilize the object [cup, etc.] should not touch the object). Do not secure a bandage over the top of the cup or other device. If feasible, elevate the head of bed (HOB) to 30 degrees to decrease intraocular pressure.
E • For blunt traumatic injuries, assess orbital stability and extraocular movements
(EOMs). Cover both eyes. If feasible, elevate the HOB to 30 degrees to decrease intraocular pressure.
• For traumatic enucleation, cover the open socket with a saline moistened dressing and cover the unaffected eye.
• For chemical eye injuries, flush affected eye with a copious amount (minimum 2L) of water or LACTATED RINGERS (preferred) or NORMAL SALINE for a period of minutes (double eversion of the lids will facilitate irrigation). Treat as indicated per the Chemical and Electrical Burn Injury Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
A • For patients with penetrating ocular injuries (including impaled ocular objects), ONDANSETRON 4mg (pediatrics 0.2 mg/kg, maximum 4 mg) PO/ODT/IV.
• For patients with penetrating ocular injuries (including impaled ocular objects), ONDANSETRON 4mg [pediatrics 0.2 mg/kg, maximum 4 mg] PO/ODT/IV.
• For patients with ocular flash burns related to welding, consider TETRACAINE
0.5% or PROPARACAINE 0.5% 2 drops to the affected eye.
• For patients with chemical eye injuries: TETRACAINE 0.5% or PROPARACAINE 0.5% 2 drops to the affected eye every
P minutes to facilitate irrigation.
Consider irrigation utilizing a Morgan Lens©.
Utilizing a pH test strip, check the ocular pH prior to and every five minutes following irrigation with 2L of fluid. Continue irrigation until the measured pH is
7.0-7.3.
NOTES:
• Consider consultation with receiving facility regarding timely availability of resources (ophthalmology services). Penetrating global injuries will require emergent in-hospital intervention.
• Patients with severe ocular injuries can present with normal visual acuity (Va).
• Orbital fractures may be associated with cranial nerve injury/entrapment or global injuries. Frequent reassessments of visual acuity and extra-ocular eye movements (EOMs) are warranted in patients with suspected orbital fractures.
• For patients with ocular complaints, determine if there is a history of use of tools or equipment with a risk for ocular injury.

04.12.title: Heat Related Illness
04.12.content:
Recognition:
Heat cramps: normal to elevated body temperature, moist skin, weakness, muscle cramps.
Heat exhaustion: elevated body temperature, cool and moist skin, weakness, anxiety, tachypnea.
Heat stroke: elevated body temperature [usually >104°F], hot and dry skin, altered mental status, +/-hypotension.
Exertional Heat Stroke (EHS): core body temperature >104°F with CNS dysfunction during or after exertion/sporting event, etc.
“COOL FIRST, TRANSPORT SECOND”
• Routine patient care.
• Measure and document body temperature in all patients with signs/symptoms of hyperthermia or other heat related illness. Core temperature shall be monitored in
E patients with suspected heat stroke/exertional heat stroke.
• Institute passive cooling measures including removing the patient from the heated environment to a cool environment and remove extra clothing.
• Heat cramps: provide oral rehydration as tolerated. Monitor and reassess.
• Heat exhaustion: institute active cooling measures including ice applied to the groin, axillae, neck and head, wet sheets placed over the patient, water immersion therapy, and utilization of the mist and fan technique. If the patient is hypotensive, manage per the age appropriate General Shock and Hypotension Protocol.
• Heat stroke: manage as above for heat exhaustion and per the age appropriate
Airway Management Protocol and Altered Mental Status Protocol.
• Exertional heat stroke: request ALS, if available, and rapidly cool patient in cold water immersion or ice-wet towels. Check core body temperature (rectal) every 5 minutes. “Cool First, Transport Second”
Active cooling measures should be discontinued when the patient’s body temperature reaches 102°F to prevent hypothermia.
• Transport the patient to nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. For heat exhaustion, heat stroke and exertional heat stroke, transport patient only after adequate cooling has occurred.
• Heat exhaustion, NORMAL SALINE 500 ml IV (pediatrics 20 ml/kg), repeat as needed to achieve a SBP >100 or an age appropriate BP in the pediatric patient (adults 2L maximum, pediatrics 60 ml/kg maximum ).
• Heat stroke, NORMAL SALINE (chilled preferred) 1000 ml IV (pediatrics 20ml/kg), repeat as needed to achieve a SBP >100 or an age appropriate BP in the pediatric
C patient (2L maximum for adults, 60 ml/kg maximum for pediatrics).
• Exertional heat stroke: NORMAL SALINE (chilled preferred) 1000 ml IV (pediatrics 20ml/
P kg), repeat as needed to achieve a SBP >100 or an age appropriate BP in the pediatric patient (2L maximum for adults, 60 ml/kg maximum for pediatrics).
• Continuously monitor core body temperature (rectal temperature) and continuous cardiac monitoring.
NOTES:
• Patients at the extremes of age (pediatric or geriatric) are at a greater risk for heat related illness. Other factors predisposing to heat related illness include exposure to increased temperature and/or humidity, poor PO intake, and extreme exertion.
• Certain medications may predispose a patient to heat related illness, including tricyclic antidepressants, phenothiazines, anticholinergics, selective serotonin uptake inhibitors and alcohol.
• Certain medications may by themselves increase body temperature, including cocaine, amphetamines and salicylates.
• Heat cramps are not associated with an increased body temperature and are the result of dehydration. They rapidly resolve following rehydration.
• If a commercially available sports drink is used for oral rehydration, it should be diluted 50/50 with water.
• If water immersion therapy is utilized, the patient should have at least their torso submerged, if not their whole body (excluding their head).
Consensus Statement - Prehospital Care of Exertional Heat Stroke s

04.13A.title: Hypothermia and Localized Cold Injury - Adult
04.13A.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with core temperature < 35° C (95°F).
• Patient with cold thermal injury (frostbite).
• Routine patient care.
• Provide airway management as indicated per the age appropriate Airway Management Protocol.
• In the unresponsive patient, allow 60 seconds for assessment for the presence of pulse.
• For patients with altered mental status, also manage per the age appropriate Altered Mental Status Protocol.
• If the patient is in cardiac arrest or cardiac arrest develops, manage per age appropriate Cardiac Arrest Protocol while starting warming measures below.
• Determine body temperature.
• For patients with a core temperature ≥ 34-35°C (93.2-95.0°F), start external rewarming measures including removing wet clothing, drying the patient, and warming the patient by use of a heat reflective shield or blankets and increasing the ambient temperature.
E • For patients with a core temperature < 34°C (93.2°F), manage as above and administer, if available, warmed (42-45°C/104-113°F) HUMIDIFIED AIR or OXYGEN.
• For patients with localized cold thermal injury, provide general wound care as l indicated per the Wound Care Treatment Protocol. Do not rub the skin to rewarm and do not allow refreezing to occur. Provide analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. l
A • For patients with a core temperature < 34°C (93.2°F), administer warm (40-42°C / 104- -
107°F) NORMAL SALINE 500 ml IV, repeat as needed unless signs/symptoms of pulmonary edema develop (maximum 2L).
NOTES:
• Mild hypothermia = 32-35°C/90-95°F, moderate = 28-32°C/82.4-90°F, severe < 28°C/82.4°F.
• Hypothermia can occur in a warm environment and indoors especially in the elderly, children, patients with impaired thermoregulation (EtOH, burns, sepsis, patients on phenothiazines, barbiturates), patients with endocrine disorders (adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism).
• Patients with moderate-severe hypothermia are typically dehydrated, rapid volume expansion with warmed IVF is critical.
• During the course of hypothermia, patients initially manifest tachycardia and then progressively become bradycardic. If paradoxical tachycardia is present, consider hypoglycemia, hypovolemia, and toxic ingestion.
• Waveform capnography may aid in identifying the presence of cardiac output in the severely hypothermic patient without a palpable pulse but with organized electrical activity on the ECG.
• Contrary to popular teaching and belief, a multicenter study (Ann Emerg. Med, 1987) found endotracheal intubation does not induce dysrhythmias in the hypothermic patient.
• The myocardium becomes irritable at ≤ 32°F. Ventricular fibrillation or asystole may occur spontaneously.

04.13P.title: Hypothermia and Localized Cold Injury - Pediatric
04.13P.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with core temperature < 35°C (95°F).
• Patient with cold thermal injury (frostbite).
• Routine patient care.
• Provide airway management as indicated per the age appropriate Airway Management Protocol.
• In the unresponsive patient, allow 60 seconds for assessment for the presence of pulse.
• For patients with altered mental status, also manage per age appropriate Altered Mental Status Protocol.
• If the patient is in cardiac arrest or cardiac arrest develops, manage per age appropriate Cardiac Arrest Protocol while starting warming measures below.
• Determine body temperature.
• For patients with a core temperature ≥ 34-35°C (93.2-95.0°F), start external r
E rewarming measures including removing wet clothing, drying the patient, and j warming the patient by use of a heat reflective shield or blankets and increasing the ambient temperature.
• For patients with a core temperature < 34°C (93.2°F), manage as above and administer, if available, warmed (42-45°C/104-113°F) HUMIDIFIED AIR or OXYGEN.
• For patients with localized cold thermal injury, provide general wound care as indicated per the Wound Care Treatment Protocol. Do not rub the skin to rewarm and do not allow refreezing to occur. Provide analgesia as indicated per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. -
Consider transportation to a Pediatric Care Specialty Facility.
A • For patients with a core temperature < 34°C (93.2°F), administer warm (40-42°C/104-
107°F) NORMAL SALINE 20 ml/kg IV, repeat as needed unless signs/symptoms of pulmonary edema develop (60 ml/kg maximum).
NOTES:
• Mild hypothermia = 32-35°C/90-95°F, moderate = 28-32°C/82.4-90°F, severe < 28°C/82.4°F.
• Hypothermia can occur in a warm environment and indoors especially in the elderly, children, patients with impaired thermoregulation (EtOH, burns, sepsis, patients on phenothiazines, barbiturates), patients with endocrine disorders (adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism).
• Patients with moderate-severe hypothermia are typically dehydrated, rapid volume expansion with warmed IVF is critical.
• During the course of hypothermia, patients initially manifest tachycardia and then progressively become bradycardic. If paradoxical tachycardia is present, consider hypoglycemia, hypovolemia, and toxic ingestion.
• Waveform capnography may aid in identifying the presence of cardiac output in the severely hypothermic patient without a palpable pulse but with organized electrical activity on the ECG.
• Contrary to popular teaching and belief, a multicenter study (Ann Emerg Med, 1987) found endotracheal intubation does not induce dysrhythmias in the hypothermic patient.
• The myocardium becomes irritable at ≤ 32°F. Ventricular fibrillation or asystole may occur spontaneously.

04.14.title: Submersion - Near Drowning
04.14.content:
Recognition:
• Submersion in water regardless of depth.
• Routine patient care.
• Apply Spinal Motion Restriction Precautions, if indicated.
• For patients in cardiac arrest, manage per the age appropriate Cardiac Arrest
Protocol.
• Manage per the age appropriate Hypothermia and Local Cold Injury Protocol as indicated.
• Remove wet clothing, dry and warm the patient.
• Manage per the age appropriate Airway Management Protocol and Altered Mental Status Protocol as indicated.
• If dyspnea or wheezing are present, manage per the age appropriate Respiratory Distress (Asthma/COPD/RAD) Protocol and consider continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) @ 5-10 cmH 0 if tolerated.
• Monitor and reassess the patient.
• Encourage transport and evaluation even if asymptomatic (asymptomatic near drowning patients should be observed for 4-6 hours for the development of complications).
-
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
E r
NOTES:
• Cardiac arrest following sudden immersion in near-freezing water may be survivable even after several hours of immersion.
• Hypothermia is commonly associated with submersion/near drowning.
• Post submersion patients who are awake and cooperative with respiratory distress may benefit from continuous positive airway pressure.

04.15.title: Diving Emergencies
04.15.content:
Recognition:
• Ear squeeze/sinus squeeze: ear pain, +/- vertigo, +/- recent history of upper respiratory infection (URI), sinus pain, difficulty equilibrating.
• Pulmonary overpressure syndrome (POPS): breath holding on ascent, respiratory distress, subcutaneous emphysema, +/- decreased BS/pneumothorax.
• Arterial gas embolism (AGE): altered mental status, sensory or motor deficits, unequal pupils, vertigo, visual disturbances, and cardiac arrest.
• Decompression sickness (DCS) Type I (non-systemic/musculoskeletal): joint pain (shoulder and elbow most common), back pain, priapism, pruritis, spotted pallor.
• Decompression sickness (DCS) Type II (systemic or neurologic): +/- DCS type I symptoms, paresthesia, paralysis, dizziness/vertigo, dyspnea, hemoptysis, auditory disturbances, chest pain, altered mental status.
• Nitrogen narcosis: “intoxicated appearing,” inattention, decreased coordination, poor judgment.
• Routine patient care.
• Determine diving history/profile: Time of symptom onset;
Parameters of the dive: depth, number of dives, duration, surface intervals;
History of air travel following the dive;
Rate of ascent;
Panic or other factors resulting in rapid ascent;
Experience level of the diver;
Properly functioning depth gauge;
Gas mixture used;
Past medical history;
Previous episodes of decompression illness; and Use of medications/alcohol.
• Consider consulting the Divers Alert Network (DAN) at 919-684-9111.
• For patients with suspected ear or sinus squeeze:
Provide analgesia per age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
Patients with ear squeeze require further evaluation to rule out tympanic membrane rupture.
• For patients with suspected pulmonary over pressure syndrome:
E OXYGEN at the highest concentration possible.
Treat shock, cardiac arrhythmias or suspected pneumothorax per appropriate protocols.
Arrange for emergent recompression therapy (consider utilizing helicopter emergency medical services [HEMS] in consultation with MEDICAL CONTROL .
for transportation of the patient to an emergency hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) capable facility).
• For patients with suspected arterial gas embolism: OXYGEN at the highest concentration possible.
Arrange for emergent recompression therapy (consider utilizing HEMS in consultation with MEDICAL CONTROL for transportation of the patient to an emergency HBO capable facility).
Transport the patient in the supine position or on their left side with their head down 30 degrees.
• For patients with suspected decompression sickness type I: OXYGEN at the highest concentration possible.
Arrange for expedient recompression therapy.
• For patients with suspected nitrogen narcosis: OXYGEN at the highest concentration possible. Manage per the age appropriate Altered Mental Status Protocol as indicated.
• For patients with suspected decompression sickness type II:
Administer OXYGEN at the highest concentration possible.
Arrange for emergent recompression therapy (consider utilizing HEMS in consultation with MEDICAL CONTROL for transportation of the patient to an emergency HBO capable facility).
• For patients with suspected decompression sickness type II, administer NORMAL SALINE 1L IV BOLUS, then NORMAL SALINE at 100 ml/hr.
• For patients with suspected decompression sickness type II, administer NORMAL SALINE 1L IV BOLUS, then NORMAL SALINE at 100 ml/hr.
• For patients with suspected “ear or sinus squeeze”:
Provide analgesia per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
OXYMETAZOLINE 2 sprays to each nostril.
C ⃝ i If available, PSEUDOEPHEDRINE 30 mg PO.
Patients with ear squeeze require further evaluation to rule out tympanic
P membrane rupture.
NOTES:
• Clinical manifestations of diving related emergencies may be seen during diving or up to 24-48 . hours following a dive.
• The main pathologies involved in diving emergencies include barotrauma, decompression illness or the toxic effects of increased partial pressure of gases.
• Any person using SCUBA equipment experiencing neurologic deficits during or after ascent should be suspected of having an arterial gas embolism (AGE).
• Signs and symptoms of AGE manifest immediately upon surfacing or during ascent.
• Nitrogen narcosis usually occurs below the surface and is a result of nitrogen’s effect on cerebral function. It may be manifested by a diver seemingly taking unnecessary risks during the dive or appearing intoxicated after surfacing.

04.16.title: Marine Envenomation
04.16.content:
Recognition:
• Exposure to marine organism with intense localized pain, nausea/vomiting, allergic reaction or anaphylactic reaction.
• Routine patient care.
• Manage allergic or anaphylactic reactions per age appropriate Allergic Reaction-
Anaphylaxis Protocol.
• Identify organism involved.
• Consider consulting the Regional Center for Poison Control and Prevention: 1-800-222-1222 for advice.
• For patients with sting ray, lionfish, urchin or starfish related injuries: Immobilize injury. Remove barb or spine, if a large barb is in thorax or abdomen, immobilize it. If able, immerse the affected area in hot water (110 - 114°F/43.3 - 45°C). Treat pain per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
E ⃝
• For patients with jellyfish or hydrozoa (Portuguese man o’ war) related injuries: Immobilize injury. Lift away tentacles, using tweezers (do not rub or brush). Irrigate using seawater, if available, or warm normal saline for approximately ti 20 minutes to deactivate toxins. Do not use fresh water. After rinsing, apply hot pack or towel soaked in hot normal saline if heat provided relief. Use caution to not burn patient; Saline should be hot, not scalding (temperature should be 110°F-113°F). Discontinue heat application if pain increases. Treat pain per the age appropriate Patient Comfort Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility if indicated.
P • For patients with severe muscle spasms, consider CALCIUM CHLORIDE or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 1 gm IV (pediatrics 20 mg/kg) over 3 minutes.
NOTES:
• Severe allergic or anaphylactic reactions may occur in seemingly minor envenomation.
• The lion’s mane jellyfish is the most common stinging organism in Rhode Island waters.
• The Portuguese man o’ war is occasionally found in local waters.
• While stingrays and lionfish are both warm water species, both have been identified in local waters (ocean and coastal ponds, respectively) and could become more frequent visitors as coastal waters warm.
• Urchins and starfish are now less commonly seen in local waters and the species of urchins, and starfish indigenous to local waters are not venomous. Encounters with toxic urchins and starfish are likely to be related to aquarium inhabitants.
• Always use caution when dealing with jellyfish or jellyfish like tentacles; never use bare hands to touch and/or remove visible tentacles.
• Avoid the following: scraping out stinger, rinsing with cold or fresh water, applying alcohol, ethanol or ammonia, rubbing with a cloth or towel, applying a pressure bandage, rinsing with urine or meat tenderizer.
• Vinegar is thought to ease the sting for some jellyfish stings, but not others; therefore, applica- tion of vinegar is no longer recommended and replaced with the hot normal saline
• Fresh water is thought to trigger the stingers in some species, but not others. Similarly, heat improves some jellyfish stings by deactivating the venom, but worsens others.
Adjust treatment as indicated by patient symptoms.

04.17.title: Bites - Stings - Envenomation
04.17.content:
Recognition:
• Bee or wasp sting, spider, snake, feline, canine, other animal or human bite.
• Routine patient care.
• Manage allergic or anaphylactic reactions per age appropriate Allergic Reaction-
Anaphylaxis Protocol.
• Manage patient as indicated per age appropriate per age appropriate Patient
Comfort Protocol.
• Identify animal involved in as much detail as possible.
• Consider consulting the Regional Center for Poison Control and Prevention: 1-800-222-1222 for advice.
• For spider bites and bee or wasp stings:
Elevate wound to a neutral position if able.
Apply ice/cool packs to affected area.
Remove any constricting clothing, bands, or jewelry.
• For snake bites: Immobilize extremity if involved.
E ⃝ Elevate wound to a neutral position if able. ti Remove any constricting clothing, bands, or jewelry from affected extremity.
Do not apply ice.
Mark margin of swelling/redness and time.
• For feline, canine, other animal or human bites:
○ Immobilize extremity if involved.
Provide wound care per the Wound Care Treatment Protocol.
Contact and document contact with the jurisdictional animal control officer.
-
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility if indicated.
ti
-
• For patients with severe muscle spasms, consider MIDAZOLAM 0.5-2 mg (pediatrics .
0.1-0.2 mg/kg) IV over 2-3 minutes or MIDAZOLAM 1-2 mg (pediatrics 0.2 mg/kg) IN or MIDAZOLAM 5 mg IM (maximum 5 mg).
NOTES:
• Immunocompromised patients (e.g., diabetes, chemotherapy, transplant) are at increased risk for infection.
• Human bites have a higher infection rate than animal bites due to oral flora.
• Feline bites may progress to infection rapidly due to a specific bacteria (Pasteurella multicoda).
• Evidence of infection includes selling, redness, drainage, fever, and red streaking proximal to the wound.
• All carnivore bites carry the risk for rabies exposure.
• Specific snakebite antivenom treatment requires accurate species identification.

04.18A.title: Toxicological Emergencies - General - Adult
04.18A.content:
Recognition:
• Beta blockers/calcium channel blockers: bradycardia, hypotension, hyperglycemia (CCBs).
• Tricyclic antidepressants/sodium channel blocking agents: altered mental status, seizures, hypotension, QRS widening, prolonged QTC, tall R-wave in aVr.
• Opioids: altered mental status, pinpoint pupils, respiratory depression, and hypotension.
• Organophosphates/nerve agents: salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, GI distress, emesis, miosis (SLUDGEM), bradycardia, bronchospasm, or bronchorrhea.
• Anticholinergics: tachycardia, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, mental status changes.
• Routine patient care.
• Obtain history of ingestion/exposure including the substance ingested, route, quantity, time of ingestion, etiology (intentional, accidental, criminal), available medications/toxins in the home and the patient’s past medical history and medications.
• For known or suspected opioid overdose with respiratory depression/apnea, NALOXONE 0.4-4 mg IN, repeat 2.0 mg every 3-5 minutes until adequate i ventilation is restored or 10 mg is administered. Follow the recovery coach algorithm at the end of this protocol.
E • For known or suspected exposure to a nerve or organophosphate agent, manage per the Toxicological Emergencies - Nerve Agent or Organophosphate Toxicity Protocol.
• Consider contacting the Regional Center for Poison Control and Prevention: 1-800-222-1222 for advice.
A • Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
• For suspected opioid overdose, if NALOXONE has not been administered or if additive doses are required, administer NALOXONE 0.4-4 mg IN or 0.4 mg IV/IM every 3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored or 10 mg is administered.
• For suspected tricyclic antidepressant or other sodium channel blocking agent toxicity, if seizures are present or the QRS is >0.12 sec, contact MEDICAL
CONTROL for authorization to administer SODIUM BICARBONATE 50 mEq IV
(repeat every 5 minutes as indicated).
• For suspected beta blocker or calcium channel blocker (CCB) toxicity, manage as indicated per Cardiac Dysrhythmia Protocols and contact MEDICAL CONTROL for
C authorization to administer GLUCAGON 1-5 mg IV (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes) .
and CALCIUM CHLORIDE 1 gm IV or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 3 gm IV (may repeat x1).
• For suspected cyanide toxicity contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to administer (if available) HYDROXOCOBALAMIN (CYANOKIT®) 70 mg/kg IV [5 gm maximum] in 250 ml NS over 15 minutes (in cardiac arrest the dose may be given over a shorter period).
• For suspected sympathomimetic/stimulant toxicity, contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to administer MIDAZOLAM 2.5 mg IV/IN/IM (may repeat every minutes, to a maximum dose of 10mg) or LORAZEPAM 1 mg IV (may repeat every 5 minutes to a maximum of 5mg).
• For suspected opioid overdose, if NALOXONE has not been administered or if additive doses are required, administer NALOXONE 0.4-4 mg IN or 0.4 mg IV/IM every 3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored or 10 mg is administered.
• For suspected tricyclic antidepressant or other sodium channel blocking agent
toxicity:
SODIUM BICARBONATE 50 mEq IV for seizures or if the QRS is > 0.12 sec (may repeat every 5 minutes).
NOREPINEPHRINE 2-20 mcg/minutes IV for hypotension (SBP < 100).
20% IV FAT EMULSION 1.5 ml/kg IV for profound hemodynamic compromise or cardiac arrest (may repeat x2), if available.
• For suspected beta blocker or calcium channel blocker (CCB) toxicity:
Cardiac Dysrhythmia Protocols as indicated GLUCAGON 1-5 mg IV (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes).
P CALCIUM CHLORIDE 1 gm IV or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 3 gm IV (may repeat x1).
DOPAMINE 2-20 mcg/kg/minutes IV for hypotension (SBP <100).
20% FAT EMULSION 1.5 ml/kg IV for profound hemodynamic compromise or cardiac arrest (may repeat x2), if available.
• For suspected cyanide toxicity: If available, HYDROXOCOBALAMIN (CYANOKIT®) 70 mg/kg IV (5 gm maximum dose) in 250 ml NS over 15 minutes (in cardiac arrest the dose may be given over a shorter period). If available, SODIUM THIOSULFATE 12.5 gm/100 ml D W over 10 minutes.
• For sympathomimetic/stimulant toxicity, MIDAZOLAM 2.5 mg IV/IN/IM (may repeat every 5 minutes, to a maximum dose of 10mg) or LORAZEPAM 1 mg IV (may repeat every 5 minutes to a maximum of 5mg).
• For dystonic reactions, DIPHENHYDRAMINE 25-50 mg IV.
• For any ingestion of highly lipid soluble medication or substance with profound i hemodynamic compromise or cardiac arrest, 20% FAT EMULSION 1.5 ml/kg IV (may repeat dose x2), if available.
• See notes for information regarding administration of 20% fat emulsion and preparation of CYANOKIT®.
NOTES:
• For patients with chronic substance use disorder, consider contacting a recovery coach to meet the patient at the hospital. Recovery coaches may be contacted at 401-415-8833.
• Support ventilation while accurately timing NALOXONE doses to minimize withdrawal.
• RI General Laws §23-10.1-4 allows a police officer to take an individual into protective custody and transport him/her to a hospital if the officer has reason to believe that the individual is intoxicated by drugs other than alcohol and as a result is likely to injure him or herself or others if allowed to be at liberty pending examination by a physician.
• Consider polydrug overdose in all patients.
• Identification of toxidromes may help identify toxins and guide therapy.
• Consider cyanide toxicity in any patient with smoke inhalation with altered mental status and unexplained hypotension.
• Patients with suspected cyanide toxicity should be administered oxygen at the highest concentration available.
• Highly lipid soluble cardiotoxic agents include, but are not limited to local anesthetics, calcium channel blockers, beta blockers and cyclic antidepressants.
• Dystonic reactions may be associated with antipsychotic agents, neuroleptic agents, antiemetics, and other medications.
• Tricyclic toxicity can progress rapidly from alert mental status to cardiac arrest.
• 20% fat emulsion should be drawn up into a syringe and administered IV/IO push.
• To prepare hydroxocobalamin (CYANOKIT®), place the vial in an upright position; utilizing the supplied transfer spike, add 0.9% NaCl to the vial (200ml for 5gm vial) and fill to the marked line. Rock the vial for at least 60 seconds. Infuse utilizing vented IV tubing.

04.18P.title: Toxicological Emergencies - General - Pediatric
04.18P.content:
Recognition:
• Beta blockers/calcium channel blockers: bradycardia, hypotension, hyperglycemia [CCB].
• Tricyclic antidepressants/sodium channel blocking agents: altered mental status, seizures, hypotension, QRS widening, prolonged QTC, tall R in aVr.
• Opioids: altered mental status, pinpoint pupils, respiratory depression, and hypotension.
• Organophosphates/nerve agents: salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, GI distress, emesis [SLUDGE].
• Routine patient care.
• Obtain history of ingestion/exposure including the substance ingested, route, quantity, time of ingestion, etiology (intentional, accidental, criminal), available medications/toxins in the home and the patient’s past medical history and medications.
E • For known or suspected opioid overdose with respiratory depression/apnea in patients <20 kg, administer NALOXONE 0.1 mg/kg IN (maximum dose 2 mg) every
3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored. For patients ≥20 kg, administer NALOXONE 2 mg IN every 3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored or mg is administered.
A • For known or suspected exposure to a nerve or organophosphate agent, manage per the Toxicological Emergencies - Nerve Agent or Organophosphate Toxicity
Protocol.
• Consider consulting the Regional Center for Poison Control and Prevention: 1-800-222-1222 for advice.
• Transport the patient to nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
• For suspected opioid overdose, if NALOXONE has not been administered or if additive doses are required, for patients <20kg NALOXONE 0.1 mg/kg IN/IV/IM (maximum dose 2mg) every 3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored. For patients ≥ 20 kg, administer NALOXONE 2 mg IN or 0.4 mg IV/IM every 3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored or 10 mg is administered.
• For suspected tricyclic antidepressant or other sodium channel blocking agent c toxicity, if seizures are present or the QRS is >0.09 sec, contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to administer SODIUM BICARBONATE 1 mEq/kg IV (repeat every five minutes as indicated).
• For suspected beta blocker or calcium channel blocker (CCB) toxicity, manage as indicated per Cardiac Dysrhythmia Protocols. Contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to administer GLUCAGON 0.1 mg/kg IV [maximum 5 mg] (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes) and CALCIUM CHLORIDE 20 mg/kg IV or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 60 mg/kg IV (may repeat x1).
• For suspected cyanide toxicity, contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to 8 administer (if available) HYDROXOCOBALAMIN (CYANOKIT®) 70 mg/kg IV (5 gm . maximum) in 250 ml NS over 15 minutes (in cardiac arrest the dose may be given over a shorter period).
• For suspected sympathomimetic/stimulant toxicity, contact MEDICAL CONTROL for authorization to administer MIDAZOLAM 0.05 mg/kg IV/IN (may repeat x1 in minutes) [do not administer if < 5 kg].
• For suspected opioid overdose, if NALOXONE has not been administered or if additive doses are required, for patients <20kg consider NALOXONE 0.1 mg/kg IN/ IV/IM (maximum dose 2mg), repeat dose at 3-5 minute intervals until adequate ventilation is restored or 10mg total is administered. For patients ≥20 kg, consider NALOXONE 2 mg IN or 0.4 mg IV/IM, repeat every 3-5 minutes until adequate ventilation is restored or 10 mg is administered.
• For suspected tricyclic antidepressant or other sodium channel blocking agent
toxicity:
SODIUM BICARBONATE 50 mEq IV for seizures or the QRS is > 0.09 sec (may repeat every 5 minutes).
NOREPINEPHRINE 0.1-2 mcg/kg/minutes IV for hypotension.
Consider 20% FAT EMULSION 1.5 ml/kg IV for profound hemodynamic compromise or cardiac arrest (may repeat x2), if available.
• For suspected beta blocker or calcium channel blocker (CCB) toxicity:
Cardiac Dysrhythmia Protocols as indicated GLUCAGON 0.1 mg/kg IV [maximum 5 mg] (may repeat x1 in 15 minutes).
P ⃝
CALCIUM CHLORIDE 20 mg/kg or CALCIUM GLUCONATE 60 mg/kg IV (may repeat x1).
DOPAMINE 2-20 mcg/kg/minutes IV or EPINEPHRINE 0.1 mcg/kg/minutes IV for hypotension.
Consider 20% FAT EMULSION 1.5 ml/kg IV for profound hemodynamic compromise or cardiac arrest (may repeat x2), if available.
• For suspected cyanide toxicity: (if available) HYDROXOCOBALAMIN (CYANOKIT®) mg/kg IV [5 gm maximum dose] in 250 ml NS over 15 minutes (in cardiac arrest the dose may be given over a shorter period).
• For sympathomimetic/stimulant toxicity, MIDAZOLAM 0.05 mg/kg IV/IN (may repeat X1 in 10 minutes) [do not administer if < 5 kg].
• For dystonic reactions, DIPHENHYDRAMINE 1 mg/kg IV IV [50 mg maximum dose] [do not administer if < 5 kg].
• For any ingestion of highly lipid soluble medication or substance with profound hemodynamic compromise or cardiac arrest, 20% FAT EMULSION 1.5 ml/kg IV (may repeat x2), if available.
• See notes for information regarding administration of 20% fat emulsion and preparation of CYANOKIT®.
NOTES:
• Support ventilation while accurately timing NALOXONE doses to minimize withdrawal.
• Consider polydrug overdose in all patients.
• Identification of toxidromes may help identify toxins and guide therapy.
• Consider cyanide toxicity in any patient with smoke inhalation with altered mental status and unexplained hypotension.
• Patients with suspected cyanide toxicity should be administered oxygen at the highest concentration available.
• Dystonic reactions may be associated with antipsychotic agents, neuroleptic agents, antiemetics, and other medications.
• Tricyclic toxicity can progress rapidly from alert mental status to cardiac arrest.
• 20% fat emulsion should be drawn up into a syringe and administered IV/IO push.
• To prepare hydroxocobalamin (CYANOKIT®), place the vial in an upright position; utilizing the supplied transfer spike, add 0.9% NaCl to the vial (200ml for 5gm vial) and fill to the marked line. Rock the vial for at least 60 sec. Infuse utilizing vented IV tubing.

04.19.title: Toxicological Emergencies - Nerve Agent or Organophosphate Toxicity
04.19.content:
Recognition:
• Patient(s) with suspected or known exposure to a nerve agent or organophosphates, displaying signs and symptoms of SLUDGEM: salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastroenteritis, emesis, and miosis. Patients may also exhibit muscle twitching, seizures, respiratory arrest, and “Killer Bs”: bradycardia, bronchorrhea, and/or bronchospasm.
• Utilize appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).
• If the scene is determined to be unsafe, call for additional/appropriate resources and stage until the scene is safe.
• Ensure appropriate resources are available to perform decontamination.
• Consider activation of the CHEMPACK resources (nerve agent and organophosphate antidotes) from the RI Department of Health through Incident Command and Regional Control. Call the Center for Emergency Preparedness and Response (CEPR) 24-hour on-call phone number: 401-222-6911.
• Obtain history of ingestion/exposure. i
• Utilize the Major Incident Protocol as indicated. i
E • Routine patient care. o
• Consider consulting the Regional Poison Control Center: 1-800-222-1222 for advice.
• Transport to the nearest Hospital Emergency Facility unless otherwise directed by
RIDOH.
A • Depending on the number of patients exposed and if CHEMPACK is being deployed, RIDOH may direct EMS to transport patients to Hospital Emergency Facilities with immediately available medical countermeasures, so as to ensure prompt and appropriate care.
CEPR 24-hour on-call phone number: 401-222-6911
* See nerve agent antidotes and CHEMPACK container contents charts on the next page
• Manage seizures with a benzodiazepine as per the age appropriate Seizure
Protocol.
• Manage seizures with a benzodiazepine as per the age appropriate Seizure Protocol.
• For the patient with mild/moderate symptoms (respiratory distress + SLUDGEM), if additive doses are required, administer ATROPINE 2 mg (pediatrics 0.02 - 0.05 mg/ kg) IV/IM every 5 minutes until symptoms resolve and (if available) PRALIDOXIME 600 mg (pediatrics 15-25 mg/kg) IV over 30 minutes or IM.
P • For the patient with severe symptoms (minor + AMS or seizures), if additive doses are required, administer ATROPINE 6 mg (pediatrics 0.02- 0.05 mg/kg) IV/IM every minutes until symptoms resolve and (if available) PRALIDOXIME 600 mg (pediatric dose 15-25 mg/kg) IV over 30 minutes or IM.
If nerve agent antidotes are available, treat as below:
CHEMPACK Container Contents Item Description Quantity per case Cases
Pralidoxime 300mg autoinjector Pralidoxime autoinjector 240
Atropine sulfate 0.4mg/mL 20mL Multi-dose vial of Atropine sulfate 100
Pralidoxime 1gm injection 20mL Multi-dose vial of Pralidoxime 276
Atropen 0.5mg Atropine autoinjector 144 1
Atropen 1.0mg Atropine autoinjector 144
Atropen 2.0mg autoinjector Atropine autoinjector 136 Diazepam 5mg/mL autoinjector Diazepam autoinjector 150 Diazepam 5mg/mL vial, 10mL Multi-dose vial of Diazepam 50 Sterile water 20cc Vial of sterile water for injections 100
NOTES:
• Follow local HAZMAT protocols for decontamination and use of personal protective equipment.
• Antidotal therapy should be started as soon as symptoms appear.
• Non-symptomatic patients should be decontaminated, moved to the cold zone and monitored for signs/symptoms of toxicity.
• For pediatric patients, use pediatric atropine formulation, if available. Use the 0.5 mg dose if patient is less than 40 pounds (18 kg), 1 mg dose if patient weighs between to 90 pounds (18 to 40 kg), and 2 mg dose for patients >90 pounds (>40 kg).
• For seizure activity, any benzodiazepine by any route is acceptable, but MIDAZOLAM and LORAZEPAM are preferred over DIAZEPAM for IN and IM routes.
• For patients with major symptoms, there is no limit for atropine dosing.
• The main symptom that the atropine addresses is excessive secretions; atropine should be given until salivation improves.
• Patients exposed to nerve agents or organophosphates may not demonstrate all of the t SLUDGEM or “Killer Bs” symptoms.

04.20.title: Carbon Monoxide Exposure
04.20.content:
Recognition:
• Patient involved in fire or in a confined space / poorly ventilated area with potential for the presence of carbon monoxide (combustion of carbon containing fuels or inadequate ventila- tion of natural gas).
• Headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, blurred vision, confusion, tachycardia, palpations, tachypnea, arrhythmia, hypotension, myocardial ischemia, seizures, change in mental status, unresponsiveness.
• Routine patient care.
• OXYGEN at the highest concentration possible.
• Treat as outlined in the table below: SpCO/SpO Treatment If the patient is asymptomatic, transportation may not be required if there are no other injuries or conditions requiring evaluation or treatment. Treat cardiac, respiratory or neurologic symptoms per appropriate protocols. Transport the patient to nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. SpCO
) Unavailable If the patient is obtunded and CO poisoning is highly suspected, and the patient does not meet criteria for transportation to a Level
( Trauma Center or Burn Center, in consultation with MEDICAL
CONTROL, consider transportation of the patient to a hyperbaric
E oxygen (HBO) capable facility. See Table 2 - Point of Entry in Routine
Patient Care Protocol No further monitoring of SpCO or treatment for CO exposure is
0-5% required.
If asymptomatic, no further treatment for CO exposure is required.
A 5-15% and Treat cardiac, respiratory or neurologic symptoms per appropriate SpO > 90%
2 protocols. Transportation is required. r
> 15-25 or Treat cardiac, respiratory or neurologic symptoms per appropriate SpO <90 protocols. Transportation is required.
Treat cardiac, respiratory or neurologic symptoms per appropriate protocols. If the patient does not meet criteria for transportation to
> 25 a Level 1 Trauma or Burn Center, in consultation with MEDICAL
CONTROL, consider transportation of the patient to a hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) capable facility.
• For fire victims who are obtunded and or with unexplained hypotension, consid- er treating for cyanide toxicity per the age appropriate Toxicological Emergencies
Protocol - General.
• If a source for CO is not identified, it should be recommended the patient have their home or work environment evaluated for the presence of CO. .
• Cardiac monitoring is indicated in all symptomatic patients. Acquire a multi-lead
ECG and examine for evidence of myocardial ischemia.
NOTES:
• Common symptoms of CO poisoning include headache, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, neurologic impairments, visual disturbances, reddened eyes, chest pain, tachycardia, arrhythmia, seizures.
• Have a high index of suspicion for CO exposure in environments when there are multiple occupants or inhabitants with “flu like symptoms” and headache.
• Fetal hemoglobin has a greater affinity for CO than maternal hemoglobin. Patients who are pregnant or may be pregnant that have had exposure to CO should be advised SpCO levels measured in the field do not reflect fetal COHb levels and fetal COHb levels may be significantly higher and a hospital evaluation is recommended.
• Carbon monoxide and cyanide are both products of combustion and toxic levels of both often occur together. A low or absent detectable level of CO does not rule out the presence of cyanide.

04.21.title: Blast Injury Incident
04.21.content:
Recognition:
• Blast explosion occurring in an open space (conventional blast) or enclosed/confined space (vehicle, building, bus, train).
• Ensure scene safety.
• If possible, determine the following: Nature of incident (accidental vs. intentional terrorism). Nature of device (manufactured, improvised explosive device [IED], industrial equipment). Nature of environment (conventional blast vs. enclosed/confined space blast).
Potential for the threat of small particles of hazardous materials.
Distance from blast, +/- protective barrier.
E ⃝
• Quantify and triage patients per the Major Incident Protocol as indicated.
• When operating at the scene of a known or suspected intentional incident, be cognizant for the threat of a secondary device.
• Routine patient care.
• Manage patient as indicated per age appropriate trauma protocols and Thermal Burn Injury Protocols, Crush Injury Protocol, Radiation Incident Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility, or as directed according to the Major Incident Protocol.
NOTES: j
• Use caution when moving patients involved in an intentional blast incident. Prior to t moving any patient, observe for indications (presence of wires, lying on top of package/backpack) that he/she is not connected to a secondary device.
• Primary blast injuries are produced by contact of the blast shockwave with the body. This results in stress and shear waves within tissues. Gas filled organs (colon, lungs, ears) are at particular risk. Common primary injuries include blast lung injury, bowel perforation, splenic/hepatic rupture, tympanic membrane rupture, ocular injuries, and concussion (concussion may be present without overt signs of head injury).
• Secondary blast injuries are produced by primary fragments (pieces of exploding weapon, e.g., nails, ball bearings) and secondary fragments (environmental fragments, e.g., glass). Common secondary injuries include penetrating injuries, traumatic amputations, and lacerations.
• Tertiary blast injuries occur when the blast wave propels individuals onto surfaces/ objects or objects onto individuals. Common tertiary injuries include blunt injuries, crush syndrome, and compartment syndrome.
• Quaternary blast injuries occur secondary to heat and/or combustion. Common quaternary injuries include toxidromes from fuels or metals, burns, inhalation injury, and asphyxiation.
• Quinary blast injuries occur from specific additives, e.g., bacteria or radioactive material (“dirty bomb”).
• High-order explosives (HE) produce a supersonic over pressurization blast wave, including TNT, C-4, NTG, Symtex, and ammonium nitrate/fuel oil (ANFO).
• Low-order explosive (LE) produce a sub-sonic explosion and therefor no over pressurization shock wave is created. LE examples include pipe bombs, gun powder and pure-petroleum based bombs (Molotov cocktails).
• The HE “blast wave” (over-pressure component) should be distinguished from “blast wind” (forced super-heated air flow). The latter may be encountered with both HE and
LE.
NOTES continue on the next page...
NOTES:
• “Blast lung injury” refers to the pulmonary sequelae of exposure of the lungs to an over pressurization blast wave. It is characterized by respiratory distress (dyspnea/apnea), bradycardia, and hypotension. Hemoptysis, hypoxia, and tension pneumothorax may also be present.
• Patients with blast lung injury may require early intubation, but overly aggressive positive pressure ventilation may worsen the injury. Use low tidal volumes and avoid hyperventilation in these patients. Volume overload may also worsen lung injury. IV fluids should be administered judiciously in the setting of lung injury (maximize preload without overload).
• The risk for blast lung injury is increased with closed or confined space blasts.

04.22.title: Radiation Incident
04.22.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with radiation burn or exposure to radiation.
• Ensure scene safety.
• If the incident involves a blast, also manage per Blast Incident and Injury Protocol.
• If possible, determine the following: Need for additional resources (hazardous material decontamination team etc.).
