Exposure type: external irradiation, external contamination with radioactive material, internal contamination with radioactive material.
Quantification of exposure: generally measured in Grays/Gy (this information may be available from individuals on scene. Do not delay transportation to acquire this information).
• Quantify and triage patients as per the Major Incident Protocol as indicated.
• Routine patient care.
• Flush contact areas with NORMAL SALINE for 15 minutes.
• If there is ocular involvement, irrigate affected eye(s) with LACTATED RINGER’S or t NORMAL SALINE for 15 minutes.
• If present, manage burn injuries as per age appropriate Burn Protocols.
• Identify and manage any secondary injuries as per appropriate trauma protocols.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
ti
NOTES:
• A patient who is contaminated with radioactive material (e.g., flecks of radioactive material embedded in their clothing and skin) generally poses minimal exposure risk to EMS Healthcare Professionals.
• In general, trauma patients who have been exposed to or contaminated by radiation should be triaged and treated on the basis of the severity of their conventional traumatic injuries.

05.01A.title: Airway Management - Adult
05.01A.content:
Assess Airway and Need for Ventilatory Support
Administer Loss of airway protective reflexes (ability to cough, swallow, GCS <8) supplemental
NO or inadequate respiratory rate or tidal volume oxygen to maintain SpO
Basic Airway Maneuvers:
Foreign Body
Chin lift—Jaw thrust
E Airway Obstruction Nasal or oral airway adjunct
(FBAO) Tracheostomy Tube Management Protocol if indicated
YES

NO with an advanced airway in place

Protocol
1. The risk of endotracheal intubation in the field should be weighed against the option of transport.
2. Airway protective reflexes include the ability to cough and swallow secretions. Contrary to common EMS teaching, gag reflex is not an airway protective reflex.
3. The most important and most difficult to use airway device is the bag-valve-mask device.
The EMS healthcare professional must master the skill of BVM ventilation.
4. An intubation attempt is defined as the introduction of a laryngoscope blade, endotracheal tube or BIAD beyond the patient’s lips or the insertion of an endotracheal tube into the patient’s nasal passage.
5. A failed airway is defined as the inability to ventilate and oxygenate after one (1) unsuccessful intubation attempt and anatomy inconsistent with continued attempts or three (3) unsuccessful attempts by the most experienced C/P or the inability to maintain oxygenation with BVM techniques and insufficient time to attempt alternative maneuvers.
6. The BURP (backwards, upward, rightward pressure over the larynx) maneuver may facilitate visualization of the glottic structures. Use of the Sellick maneuver (cricoid pressure) is not useful in aiding visualization of the glottic structures.
7. When possible, spontaneously breathing patients should be preoxygenated with high concentration oxygen via a nonrebreather mask combined with a nasal cannula (set at high flow) or with a BVM device attached to supplemental oxygen with a reservoir
(preferably spontaneously breathing against mask seal without interposed positive pressure ventilation if rate and tidal volume allow) with a nasal cannula (set at high flow) or with CPAP. If used, the nasal cannula should be left in place during intubation.
8. All advanced airway management, including blindly inserted airway device (BIAD) insertion, intubation, and insertion or intubation attempts made by EMS healthcare professionals shall be thoroughly documented in both the narrative and drop-down procedure section of the patient care report (PCR). Additionally, evidence of continuous waveform capnography confirming proper endotracheal tube placement and adequate ventilation is MANDATORY and must be documented in the PCR. If available, continuous waveform capnography must also be used to confirm the proper placement of BIADs. If waveform capnography is used for the confirmation of the proper placement of a BIAD, capnography waveforms must be uploaded into the PCR. If waveform capnography is unavailable for confirmation of proper BIAD placement, a colorimetric end-tidal CO detection device shall be utilized. This is a standard of practice that applies to all advanced airways placed by EMS healthcare professionals and for any patient with an advanced airway in place under the care of EMS healthcare professionals during interfacility transfers.
9. The name of the physician who accepts a patient with an advanced airway in place shall be documented in the narrative section of the PCR.
10. All advanced airway management, including BIAD insertion, intubation and intubation attempts made by EMS healthcare professionals shall be reviewed by the EMS agency Medical Director.
11. Consider the following in airway assessment:
Difficult BVM Ventilation (MOANS):
M: Difficult mask seal due to facial hair, blood/secretions, anatomy, or trauma O: Obesity or late pregnancy
A: Age (>55) N: No teeth S: Stiff or increased airway pressures (asthma, COPD, obesity, pregnancy) Difficult Laryngoscopy (LEMON) L: Look externally for anatomic distortions (small mandible, short neck, large tongue)
E: Evaluate using the 3-3-2 rule (mouth opening should accommodate 3 patient fingers, mandible to neck distance should accommodate 3 patient fingers, chin-neck junction to thyroid prominence should accommodate 2 patient fingers) M: Mallampati score (difficult to evaluate in the field or critically ill patient) O: Obstruction (anatomic, pregnancy, obese) N: Neck mobility (limited due to pathology, collar)
Difficult BIAD Insertion/ventilation (RODS):
R: Restricted mouth opening O: Obstruction/obese/late pregnancy D: Distorted or disrupted airway S: Stiff lungs/increased airway pressure (asthma, COPD, obese, pregnant)
12. When intubating or placing a BIAD in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury, maintain in-line cervical stabilization and remove the anterior section of the cervical collar to allow anterior mandibular mobility.
13. Nasotracheal intubation requires spontaneous ventilation. Colorimetric EtCO detection devices are not reliable for confirmation of a nasally placed endotracheal tube.
14. Paramedics should place a gastric tube in all intubated patients.
15. The use of continuous quantitative waveform is MANDATORY in all patients with an endotracheal tube in place.

Protocol
1. The risk of endotracheal intubation in the field should be weighed against the option of transport.
2. Airway protective reflexes include the ability to cough and swallow secretions. Contrary to common EMS teaching, gag reflex is not an airway protective reflex.
3. The most important and most difficult to use airway device is the bag-valve-mask device. EMS healthcare professionals must master the skill of BVM ventilation.
4. An intubation attempt is defined as the introduction of a laryngoscope blade, endotracheal tube or BIAD beyond the patient’s lips or the insertion of an endotracheal tube into the patient’s nasal passage.
5. A failed airway is defined as the inability to ventilate and oxygenate after one (1) unsuccessful intubation attempt and anatomy inconsistent with continued attempts or three (3) unsuccessful attempts by the most experienced EMS healthcare professional
(patient age appropriate), or the inability to maintain oxygenation with BVM techniques and insufficient time to attempt alternative maneuvers.
6. The BURP (backwards, upward, rightward pressure over the larynx) maneuver may facilitate visualization of the glottic structures. Use of the Sellick maneuver (cricoid pressure) is not useful in aiding glottis visualization.
7. When possible, spontaneously breathing patients should be preoxygenated with high concentration oxygen via a nonrebreather mask combined with a nasal cannula (set at high flow) or with a BVM device attached to supplemental oxygen with a reservoir
(preferably spontaneously breathing against mask seal without interposed positive pressure ventilation if rate and tidal volume allow) with a nasal cannula (set at high flow) or with CPAP. If used, the nasal cannula should be left in place during intubation.
8. In the pediatric patient, anticipate a higher and more anterior glottic opening.
9. Maintain the patient in the sniffing position. Do not hyperextend the neck. A towel may be required under the shoulders to elevate the torso relative the head in small infants.
10. A straight laryngoscope blade should be used in the patient < 3 years of age.
11. When intubating or placing a BIAD in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury, maintain in-line cervical stabilization and remove the anterior section of the cervical collar to allow anterior mandibular mobility.
12. Paramedics should place a gastric tube in all intubated patients and pediatric patients receiving positive pressure ventilation via mask.
13. The use of continuous quantitative waveform is MANDATORY in all patients with an endotracheal tube in place.
14. All advanced airway management, including blindly inserted airway device (BIAD) insertion, intubation, and insertion or intubation attempts made by EMS healthcare professionals shall be thoroughly documented in both the narrative and drop-down procedure section of the patient care report (PCR). Additionally, evidence of continuous waveform capnography confirming proper airway placement and ventilation must be documented in the PCR. Capnography waveform must be uploaded into the PCR.
This is a standard of practice that applies to all advanced airways placed by EMS healthcare professionals and for any patient with an advanced airway in place under the care of EMS healthcare professionals during interfacility transfer.
13. The name of the physician who accepts a patient with an advanced airway in place must be documented in the narrative section of the PCR.
14. All advanced airway management, including BIAD insertion, intubation and intubation attempts made by EMS healthcare professionals must be reviewed by the EMS agency Medical Director.

05.02A.title: Failed Airway - Adult
05.02A.content:
Unable to ventilate and oxygenate adequately after one (1) or more unsuccessful intubation attempt
AND
Anatomy inconsistent with continued attempts
OR Three (3) unsuccessful attempts by most experienced C/P
NO MORE THAN THREE (3) ATTEMPTS TOTAL
OR Inability to maintain oxygenation with BVM techniques and insufficient time to attempt alternative maneuvers.
Call for additional resources, if Failed airway available BVM ventilations with airway adjunct maintains SpO YES
≥90% or acceptable value based upon clinical condition
NO
E BIAD Continue BVM ventilation u with supplemental oxygen.
Expedite transport. Exit to appropriate protocol.
E Reposition. Reattempt.
NO Focus on BVM skills. BIAD successful?
P Cricothyrotomy YES
Continue ventilation/oxygenation.
Maintain SpO between 94-99% Ventilate to maintain EtCO between 35-45 mmHg Notify hospital destination or
Contact Medical Control
1. A failed airway occurs when an EMS healthcare professional begins a course of airway management by endotracheal intubation and identifies that intubation by that method will not succeed.
2. The most important way to avoid a failed airway situation is to identify patients with an expected difficult airway, difficult BVM ventilation, difficult BIAD insertion, difficult laryngoscopy and/or difficult cricothyrotomy.
3. Improper positioning is commonly responsible for failed and difficult intubations in the field. Understanding that the prehospital setting is unique and has many challenges, attempts to properly position the patient must be undertaken. The “sniffing position” or simply the head extended upon the neck are probably the best positions to facilitate airway management. The goal is to align the ear canal with the suprasternal notch in straight line.
4. In obese or patients in late pregnancy, elevating the torso with blankets, pillows or towels will optimize patient position. This can also be accomplished by elevating the head of the ambulance cot.
5. Elevating or lowering the ambulance cot may be helpful. With the patient on the cot, raise the cot until the patient’s nose is at the level of your umbilicus.
6. When intubating or placing a BIAD in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury, maintain in-line cervical stabilization and remove the anterior section of the cervical collar to allow anterior mandibular mobility.
7. BVM ventilation can be maximized by the placement of two (2) nasopharyngeal airways and an oropharyngeal airway.
8. If the first intubation attempt is not successful, make an adjustment and consider:
• Use of a different laryngoscope blade/video or other laryngoscope device if i available
• Use of an endotracheal tube introducer
• Downsizing the ETT i
• Apply the BURP maneuver
• Change head position or the level of the patient

2. The most important way to avoid a failed airway situation is to identify patients with an expected difficult airway, difficult BVM ventilation, difficult BIAD insertion, difficult laryngoscopy and/or difficult cricothyrotomy.
3. Improper positioning is commonly responsible for failed and difficult intubations in the field. Understanding that the prehospital setting is unique and has many challenges, attempts to properly position the patient must be undertaken. The “sniffing position” or simply the head extended upon the neck are probably the best positions to facilitate airway management. 4. In obese or patients in late pregnancy, elevating the torso with blankets, pillows or towels will optimize patient position. This can also be accomplished by elevating the head of the ambulance cot.

05.03.title: Respiratory Distress in a Patient with a Tracheostomy Tube
05.03.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with tracheostomy tube experiencing respiratory distress, increased inspiratory time or increased resistance with use of manual resuscitation bag.
• Routine patient care.
• If there is no tracheostomy tube in place: If a tracheostomy tube is available, allow a caregiver to insert the tracheostomy tube or place the tracheostomy tube into the stoma. If there is continued respiratory distress following replacement of the tracheostomy tube and a caregiver trained tracheostomy tube management is present, have the caregiver suction the tracheostomy tube.
• If there is a tracheostomy tube in place and a caregiver trained in tracheostomy
tube management is present, suggest the following:
If an obturator is in place, remove the obturator and reassess.
E ⃝ If a speaking valve or decannulating plug is in place, remove the valve or plug, t suction the tracheostomy tube and reassess.
If an inner cannula (IC) is in place, remove and inspect the IC, clear/clean as needed and reassess after removal of the IC. If there is continued respiratory distress, the tracheostomy tube should be suctioned. r
• If there is continued respiratory distress after the above, provide assisted ventilation as needed via the tracheostomy tube with a manual resuscitation bag and manage as indicated per the age appropriate Respiratory Distress (Asthma/
COPD/RAD) Protocol.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. t ti
• If there is no tracheostomy tube in place:
○ Insert a tracheostomy tube (if available) or an appropriate size ETT into the stoma.
○ If there is continued respiratory distress following replacement of the i tracheostomy tube/ETT, suction the tube.
○ Provide assisted ventilation via the tracheostomy tube with a manual r resuscitation bag if indicated. Manage as indicated per the age appropriate Respiratory Distress (Asthma/
COPD/RAD) Protocol. i
• If there is a tracheostomy tube in place: s If an obturator is in place, remove the obturator and reassess. If a speaking valve or decannulating plug is in place, remove the valve or plug,
P ⃝ suction the tracheostomy tube and reassess.
If an inner cannula (IC) is in place, remove and inspect the IC, clear/clean as needed and reassess after removal of the IC. If there is continued respiratory distress, suction the tracheostomy tube.
○ Provide assisted ventilation via the tracheostomy tube with a manual . resuscitation bag if indicated. Manage as indicated per the age appropriate Respiratory Distress (Asthma/
COPD/RAD) Protocol.
NOTES:
• Use family members/caregivers as a resource as they have knowledge and training regarding tracheostomy tube management.
• Use the patient’s equipment, if available and properly functioning.
• With certain tracheostomy tubes, patients cannot receive positive pressure ventilation without the inner cannula in place as the cannula contains the 15mm adapter required to attach a bag valve device or ventilator circuit.
• In an emergency, patients with a dislodged tracheostomy tube that cannot be reinserted should be intubated.
• A tracheostomy is not considered mature until > 7 days. Dislodgement of a tracheostomy tube from an immature stoma requires quick recognition as the stoma will begin to close. Immediate treatment includes mask ventilation and endotracheal intubation.
• Always deflate the tracheal tube cuff prior to removal. t
• To quickly estimate the appropriate size suction catheter to utilize with a given tracheostomy tube, multiply the tubes inner diameter (ID) x2 and utilize the next smallest size catheter (e.g., 6.0 mm ID x 2 = 12, next smallest catheter is 10 fr.). c
• Suctioning depth is usually 3-6 cm. Ask family member/caregiver. Do not force a suction r catheter. If unable to pass a suction catheter, the tracheostomy tube should be changed.
• Do NOT suction for > 10 sec at a time. Preoxygenate before and in between attempts.
• The mnemonic DOPE is useful for trouble shooting problems with artificial airways. t
• Displaced tube
• Obstructed tube
• Pneumothorax ti
• Equipment failure

05.04.title: Medication Assisted Intubation
05.04.content:
Recognition:
• Patient ≥ 8 y.o. requiring emergent intubation. Indication
• Delayed sequence intubation (DSI): patient requiring emergent intubation who is agitated or otherwise intolerant of preoxygenation and, as such, has a SpO <94%.
• Rapid sequence intubation (RSI): patient requiring emergent intubation with an initial and maintainable SpO ≥ 94%.
1. Preparation (same for DSI and RSI):
a. Perform an airway assessment to identify potential difficulties in management ) and to determine the appropriateness of administering a paralyzing agent.
b. Identify anatomic landmarks related to performing cricothyrotomy; ensure the immediate availability of cricothyrotomy kit.
c. Determine back-up options and plan (ensure availability of back up device(s) r and resources).
d. Ensure proper monitoring is in place (SpO , EtCO , ECG, NIBP).
e. Rule out the presence of any contraindications to the medications to be utilized f. Assemble and check all required equipment as per standard routine for r intubation.
g. Ensure functional IV access (two preferred if possible).
h. Review medication dosing and draw up medications (syringes should be labeled).
i. Check availability/functionality of suction.
j. Hemodynamic optimization (fluids and push dose vasopressors) as clinically indicated to maintain SBP ≥90 mmHg. r
2. Delayed sequence intubation:
( a. Position the patient “head up” at ≥15° angle, with the auditory meatus above the jugular notch.
ti b. Sedate with KETAMINE 1 mg/kg IV administered slowly over 60 seconds (may re-dose at 0.5-1 mg/kg if dissociation does not occur within two minutes).
c. For patients with adequate minute ventilation, apply a standard nasal cannula set at ≥15 lpm (flush rate preferred) and apply a non-rebreather mask set at
≥15 lpm (flush rate preferred) and maintain for a minimum of 3 minutes. If the patient is able, coach them to take 8 vital capacitance breaths in less than seconds. If after 3 minutes the SpO 2 is <94%, utilize a bag-valve-mask device i with a one-way exhalation valve and reservoir bag attached to supplemental oxygen at ≥15 lpm with PEEP set at 10-15cmH 0 (spontaneous tidal breathing is preferred over interposed positive pressure ventilation, see NOTES below regarding required bag characteristics) or apply CPAP up to 15cmH 0. ti d. For patients with inadequate minute ventilation, apply a standard nasal cannula set at ≥15 lpm (flush rate preferred) and provide ventilatory support i with a bag-valve-mask device with a reservoir bag attached to supplemental oxygen at ≥15 LPM with PEEP set at 5-15 cmH 0.
e. Maintain the SpO
≥94% for 3 minutes (use timing device).
f. Administer ROCUROUNIUM 1.2 mg/Kg IV or SUCCINYLCHOLINE 1.5 mg/kg IV (2 mg/kg if <10 yo).
g. Ensure proper positioning to optimize visualization and minimize the rate of .
desaturation during laryngoscopy.
h. Leaving the nasal cannula in place, reduce the liter flow to 15 lpm.
i. Confirm mandibular flaccidity (60-90 seconds following the administration of rocuronium, 45 seconds following the administration of succinylcholine) and perform direct/video laryngoscopy and intubation. Continually monitor the SpO , if the SpO decreases to <94%, direct laryngoscopy/intubation should be aborted, and the patient should be gently ventilated with bag-valve-mask device. No further attempt should occur until the SpO is
≥94%. The SpO nadir during this time should be documented.
J. Confirm endotracheal tube placement by directly visualizing the ETT passing through the vocal cords, presence of a capnography waveform for ≥ 6 breaths and the presence of breath sounds.
3. Rapid sequence intubation:
a. If possible, position the patient “head up” at ≥15° angle, with the auditory meatus above the jugular notch.
b. For patients with adequate minute ventilation, apply a standard nasal cannula
) set at ≥15 lpm (flush rate preferred) and apply a non-rebreather mask set at l
≥15 lpm (flush rate preferred, if the patient is able, coach them to take 8 vital capacitance breaths in less than 60 seconds) or apply CPAP up to 15cmH 0. For patients with inadequate minute ventilation, apply a standard nasal cannula set at ≥15 lpm (flush rate preferred) and provide ventilatory support with a bag- valve-mask device with a reservoir bag attached to supplemental oxygen at ≥15 LPM with PEEP set at 5-15cmH 0.
c. Maintain the SpO 2 ≥94% for 3 minutes (use timing device). i r d. Sedate with KETAMINE 1-2 mg/kg IV over 60 seconds or ETOMIDATE 0.2-0.3 mg/kg IV (reduce sedating agent dose to 1/2 if concern for hypotension exists).
e. Reposition the patient as needed to optimize visualization and minimize the rate of desaturation during laryngoscopy.
f. Administer neuromuscular blocking agent of choice ROCURONIUM 1.2mg/kg or i SUCCINYLCHOLINE 1.5mg/kg IV (2 mg/kg if <10 yo).
g. Ensure proper positioning to optimize visualization and minimize the rate of desaturation during laryngoscopy.
h. Leaving the nasal cannula in place, reduce the liter flow to 15 lpm.
P ( i. Confirm mandibular flaccidity (60-90 seconds following the administration of rocuronium, 45 seconds following the administration of succinylcholine) and ti perform direct/video laryngoscopy and intubation (the nasal cannula set at flush rate should be left in place until ETT placement is confirmed).
j. Continually monitor the SpO , if the SpO decreases to <94%, direct laryngoscopy/intubation should be aborted, and the patient should be gently ventilated/oxygenated with a BVM device. Further attempt(s) should not occur until the SpO 2 is ≥94%. The SpO 2 nadir during this time should be documented. t k. Confirm endotracheal tube placement by directly visualizing the ETT passing through the vocal cords, presence of a capnography waveform for ≥ 6 breaths and the presence of breath sounds.
4. Post-intubation management: ti a. Provide standard management for the patient with an advanced airway in place. Continuous quantitative capnography is mandatory. i b. Provide analgesia, sedation and neuromuscular blockade as indicated
(remember, the effects of rocuronium remain for 30-60 minutes, paralysis without sedation must be avoided).
c. When ventilating a patient post intubation, maintain the pre-intubation respiratory rate if it was high as it is most likely compensation for metabolic acidosis.
d. Be prepared for post intubation hypotension and maintain hemodynamics with .
IV fluids and vasopressors as needed.
e. Perform gastric decompression by placing a gastric tube.
NOTES:
• Execution of this protocol is restricted to Paramedics who have completed the prerequisite CEMS and EMS agency Medical Director competency requirements.
• When a BVM is used for preoxygenating a spontaneously breathing patient (i.e., no positive pressure breaths), the BVM must contain a one-way exhalation valve and reservoir bag and the supplemental oxygen flow must be sufficient to match the patients minute ventilation.
• Use of a sedating agent alone to facilitate intubation is considerably less desirable than utilizing a sedating agent in combination with a neuromuscular blocking agent. First attempt success rates are significantly increased utilizing a neuromuscular blocking
) agent. l
• In the pre-arrest patient, a “crash sequence” utilizing only succinylcholine or c Rocuronium may be indicated. These situations are extremely rare and subsequent sedation must be provided when hemodynamically permissible.
• Hemodynamic optimization with fluids and vasopressors should occur prior to intubation. Preload dependent patients (i.e., history of asthma) and others sensitive to positive pressure ventilation should be volume loaded prior to the institution of positive pressure ventilation. i
• MAI includes rapid sequence intubation (the nearly simultaneous administration of a sedating agent and a short acting neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate intubation) and delayed sequence intubation (procedural sedation with the procedure being preoxygenation).
• Contraindications to succinylcholine include a patient or family history of malignant i hyperthermia, burns, major crush injury injuries, denervation (spinal cord injury or CVA with paralysis) >24 hrs. (for the purposes of this protocol), myopathy, and preexisting hyperkalemia.
• The onset of action and duration of action of succinylcholine is 45 seconds and 6-10 ( minutes respectively. The onset of action and duration of action of rocuronium is 60-90 seconds and 30-60 minutes respectively.
ti
• Underdosing of rocuronium may result if the drug is administered based upon ideal, rather than actual body weights. For obese patients, rocuronium dosing should be based upon actual body weight.
• The onset of action and duration of action of etomidate is 15-45 seconds and 3-12 minutes respectively. The onset of action and duration of action of ketamine is 45-60 seconds and 10-20 minutes respectively.
• In both adults and pediatric patients, a repeat dose of succinylcholine may result in bradycardia requiring the administration of atropine sulfate.
• There is concern in the literature that etomidate may inhibit endogenous cortisol production secondary due to inhibition of 11-β-hydroxylase in the adrenal cortex. While there has been no large, randomized, prospective, adequately powered study ti that has demonstrated a significant negative effect associated with the administration of etomidate in the setting of sepsis, some healthcare professionals avoid the use of i etomidate in this setting.
• Very rarely the administration of succinylcholine may result in isolated masseter spasm causing mandibular rigidity (trismus) with limb muscle flaccidity. If this occurs and interferes with intubation, a non-depolarizing agents (rocuronium 1 mg/kg) should be . administered. The patient may require bag mask ventilation until complete muscle relaxation occurs.
• Fasciculations following the administration of succinylcholine are generally of no clinical significance.
• If hypotension ensues following the administration of ketamine, address the blood pressure prior to administering a paralytic.

06.01.title: Major Incident (Multiple Patient / Mass Casualty Incident)
06.01.content:
06.01 Major Incident (Mass Casualty Incident)
Recognition:
• A major incident is one where the report, or assessment by the first arriving unit, predicts that the incident needs will overwhelm the promptly available resources. A major incident may involve a substantial number of patients (multiple patient or mass casualty incident), or the circumstances may present a major challenge (hostage situation, technical rescue, search and rescue, etc.). The first arriving unit should establish the Incident Command System, which should inform subsequent arriving units as to logistics and needs. The patient tracking system (PTS) shall be used, through communication with the designated HOST HOSPITAL and other resources, to distribute patients if there are multiple patients.
• The unit declaring a Major Incident shall declare a MCI on PTS and notify their commu- nications center of the type of incident, approximate number of patients, and special circumstances (fire, hazardous materials, technical rescue, etc.).
• The Incident Commander should then request indicated resources using the regional mutual aid plan and notify the hospital system of the incident, allowing preparation and coordination.
• Knowledge of the START/JumpSTART Triage algorithm is recommended.
• If not done by the jurisdictional (local, system specific) communications center, Inci- dent Command should make primary declaration of a Major Incident to the HOST t HOSPITAL via the RISCON 800 MHz system on the Hospitals talk group (Wide Area 3).
• Using their knowledge of the incident and skills, responding EMS healthcare profes- i sionals should triage and treat patients logically and promptly using all indicated proto-
E cols, with the goal of maximizing survival and minimizing disability and deterioration of condition . j
• Medical Control may be obtained for the incident as a whole, either on-line or through response of an on-scene EMS physician.
• After initial triage and stabilization, transport of patients should be coordinated through the Incident Command system, with each patient categorized as Red (critical, cannot be stabilized on scene), Yellow (emergent, stabilized), Green (urgent, stable), Black (deceased/expectant).
• Use of plain language and brief descriptions is encouraged, along with carefully coordi- nated and controlled communications..
• Responding EMS healthcare professionals should use indicated PPE and clothing as ap- propriate for the expected hazards and weather / conditions at the scene.
NOTES:
• The first arriving EMS unit should determine the nature of the incident, estimated number of patients and the need for specialty resources.
• Subsequently arriving EMS units should follow direction per the ICS and respond where and as directed by IC.
• EMS healthcare professionals should maintain familiarity with the START/JumpSTART or similar algorithm and apply them if indicated with the understanding that they were devel- oped to sort patients with hemorrhagic shock in a first responder environment, and do not account for the EMS ability to treat and stabilize patients.
• In some incidents (fires, CO or chemical exposures, etc.) ambulatory patients may have serious / life threatening injuries (e.g., inhalation injury).
• Municipal services should maintain a multiple patient (mass casualty) incident plan specific to their jurisdiction/region.
• Instances of lightning strike/electrocution, the reverse triage rule applies. Patients without spontaneous circulation should be treated prior to those with spontaneous circulation. START / JumpSTART Triage Tool

06.02.title: Helicopter Emergency Medical Services (HEMS)
06.02.content:
Recognition:
• Patient with traumatic injuries or burns meeting the criteria for transportation to a Level Trauma Center or a verified Burn Center as outlined in the Multiple Trauma or Thermal Burn Injury Protocols, when ground scene to ED door transportation time is ≥ 45 minutes.
• The use of HEMS may be considered in a multiple patient incident.
• Patients with an unmanageable airway or uncontrollable hemorrhage should be transported to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility unless advanced life support or HEMS can intercept in a more timely fashion.
• Contact a HEMS agency (see Table 1 below) and determine availability and estimated time of arrival (ETA). If the ETA of HEMS will extend the arrival of the patient to the intended receiving facility beyond that of ground transportation from the scene, the patient should be transported to the nearest appropriate ) Hospital Emergency Facility.
• HEMS is not indicated for patients in cardiac arrest. If the patient experiences cardiac arrest after the request of HEMS, the patient should be transported to the
( nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. If the arrival of HEMS is imminent, the HEMS crew may be utilized for assistance in resuscitation and stabilization. Otherwise, the HEMS response should be canceled.
• Patients with exposure to hazardous materials must be decontaminated prior to the utilization of HEMS.
• Selection and preparation of a Landing Zone (LZ) should occur following local jurisdictional procedures. Radio communication with HEMS aircraft should be via the designated LZ command. Table 1 - Rhode Island Area HEMS Agencies Healthcare Professional Base Locations Communication Center
E UMass Memorial Life Flight Worcester, MA 800-343-4354 e Life Star Hartford, Norwich, CT 800-221-2569 Boston MedFlight Bedford, Lawrence, 800-233-8998
Plymouth, MA SkyHealth Ronkonkoma, NY 844-759-4584 i

06.03.title: Medical Orders for Life Sustaining Treatment / Comfort One
06.03.content:
Recognition:
• A patient with MOLST who is delineated on a R.I. Department of Health approved MOLST form (see next page for reference) which has been signed by a MOLST qualified healthcare professional (MD, DO, PA, APRN) and signed by the patient, the patient’s decision maker, parent/guardian of a minor, or guardian as per R.I. General Laws §23-4.11-3.1.
• A patient enrolled in the Comfort One program with a Comfort One bracelet affixed to their person.
• Provide routine patient care and continue or initiate resuscitative efforts per age appropriate protocols until the patient’s MOLST or Comfort One status have been verified.
• For patients with MOLST, verify the presence of an appropriately executed
MOLST form:
Provide care as outlined on the patient’s MOLST form.
If possible, determine if hospice or a home health agency is involved in the
/ patient’s care and provide appropriate notification.
Provide emotional support to the family.
• For patients with Comfort One Status, verify the presence of a Comfort One bracelet on one of the patient’s extremities or in a sealed and closed bracelet on
a neck chain. The bracelet must be intact and not defaced or damaged:
E ⃝ Do not initiate ventilatory support, external chest compressions, advanced r airway management (BIAD/intubation), cardiac monitoring, establish IV access for resuscitative purposes, or provide electrical therapy (defibrillation, pacing).
Do provide airway suctioning, manual airway management and oxygen as indicated, positioning for comfort, analgesia for pain control, and hemorrhage control.
If possible, determine if hospice or a home health agency is involved in the patient’s care and provide appropriate notification. i
Provide emotional support to the family.
• For patients with a written or electronic Do Not Resuscitate Order contained in their chart at a licensed healthcare facility, said order shall be honored by EMS in the absence of a MOLST form or Comfort One status.
NOTES:
• A patient with present capacity can, at any time, void the MOLST form or change their mind about their treatment preferences.
• A patient’s healthcare decision maker may request to modify the MOLST based on the known desires of the patient or, if unknown, the patient’s best interest.
• If the patient’s medical records contain more than one MOLST form, the most recent orders / MOLST form shall be followed.
• Regardless of their mental or physical condition, a patient may revoke their Comfort One status by directly communicating their desire to a EMS healthcare professional or . another licensed healthcare professional or by physically destroying their Comfort One bracelet or MOLST form.
• Additionally, a patient’s surrogate decision maker or another person in the patient’s presence and at the direction of the patient may revoke a patient’s Comfort One status by directly communicating this desire to a EMS healthcare professional or another licensed healthcare professional or by physically destroying the patient’s Comfort One bracelet.
• In the event the patient or other qualified individual revokes a patient’s MOLST or
Comfort One status, the revocation must be documented in the EMS PCR along with the name of the and role of the person responsible for the revocation.
/
/

06.04.title: Refusal of Patient Care or Transport
06.04.content:
Recognition:
• A patient ≥ 16 years of age with a present mental capacity who wishes to refuse patient care or transportation by EMS for themselves, or
• A parent or legal guardian of a minor patient, with a present mental capacity, who wishes to refuse patient care or transportation by EMS for their child or child under their guardianship, or
• A person with present mental capacity or a person legally designated as a healthcare proxy or of next of kin of a patient without present capacity, who wishes to refuse patient care or transportation for said patient, or
• A legally emancipated minor with present mental capacity who wishes to refuse patient care or transportation for themselves.
• A refusal of patient care is considered valid if the following three components are
established:
Competence: Patients meeting the criteria in the recognition section above are considered by the R.I. General Laws to be competent to consent to or refuse care. Parents and legal guardians, as described above, who are on scene may refuse consent to or refuse care on behalf of a minor child.
Capacity: The patient, person or legal guardian must demonstrate present mental capacity as assessed below.
Informed refusal: A patient or other responsible person must be fully informed about his or her medical/traumatic condition and the risks refusal and the benefits of treatment/transport in accordance with their presenting complaint.
• If the patient is exhibiting suicidal or homicidal ideations, contact the appropriate jurisdictional law enforcement agency.
• Perform an assessment of the patient’s medical/traumatic condition, and, to the extent permitted by the patient, a physical examination including vital signs and other indicated testing (e.g., blood glucose, ECG, etc.). This assessment, or the patient’s refusal of assessment must be fully documented on the PCR.
• Attempt to identify any patient/person/guardian perceived barriers to treatment/ ti transport and make reasonable efforts to address these barriers. This may include, but is not limited to, the offer of transportation to a licensed healthcare facility not recommended by protocol. These offers should be made only for the purpose of facilitating additional evaluation and/or treatment which would otherwise be
E refused.
• Consider consulting MEDICAL CONTROL for assistance in facilitating patient acceptance of treatment or transportation. It may be helpful to have the patient or the patient’s guardian speak directly with the MEDICAL CONTROL physician. If
MEDICAL CONTROL is consulted, it should be documented in the PCR (including the time of the consult and the name of the physician).
• Inform the patient/person/guardian of the risks of refusal and the benefits of treatment/transportation related to the presenting complaint and assessment findings. It should be explained that the list of risks described is not comprehensive due to the diagnostic limitations of the pre-hospital environment and that their refusal may result in worsening of their condition, serious disability or death. Understand that the consequences of refusal are likely more serious than the consequences of consent. The two are not equal, but opposite.
• Assess the patient for their ability to demonstrate present mental capacity by determining the following. If the answer to all three is yes, present mental capacity
is affirmed:
Does the patient/guardian understand the illness or injury and the benefits of evaluation, treatment and/or transportation by EMS?; and, Does the patient/guardian understand the consequences (including death) of not seeking evaluation, treatment and/or transport by EMS?; and, Does the patient understand alternatives to immediate evaluation, treatment and/or transportation by EMS?
• A competent patient/person/guardian who is determined to have present mental capacity that meets the following criteria may refuse evaluation, care or transport
by EMS:
The refusal is solely initiated by the patient, not suggested/prompted by EMS practitioners;
The patient is oriented to person, place, time and situation;
There is no evidence of altered consciousness resulting from head trauma, medical illness, intoxication, dementia, psychiatric illness or other etiologies;
There is no evidence of impaired judgment from alcohol or drug influence;
There is no language communication barrier (use audio and/or video interpreter services, if indicated; and There is no evidence or admission of suicidal ideation resulting in any gesture or attempt at self-harm and no verbal or written expression of suicidal ideation regardless of any apparent inability to complete a suicide attempt.
• Document the refusal of care/transportation by having the patient sign (or, in the case of a minor patient, the minor patient’s parent, legal guardian, or authorized representative) a refusal of care statement on the PCR or a standalone, service specific refusal of care form. If a standalone or service specific form is used, the form must be attached to the PCR. Documentation should also include, when possible, a signature by a witness, preferably a competent relative, friend, police officer, or impartial third party.
• Advise the patient/person/guardian that they should seek immediate medical care at an Emergency Department and that they may call 911 at any time if the medical condition changes or worsens or if they wish EMS care and transportation.
• Provide documentation on the PCR supporting the presence of mental capacity e and specific information provided to the patient/guardian regarding their condition and risks associated with the refusal of evaluation, treatment and/or transportation by EMS.
• If the patient/person/guardian refuses to sign a refusal of care statement, provide ti documentation in the PCR regarding the situation under which there was a refusal to sign.
• Documentation is required in the event of a patient refusal of care and/or transport. Documentation must include any treatments performed and a l narrative in accordance with the requirements of the Documentation Protocol.

06.05.title: Interfacility and Non-Emergent Transport
06.05.content:
Recognition:
• Interfacility transport patients should be classified and aligned with transport resources appropriate for their needs.
The following classification should be used:
BLS A patient who is clearly and completely stable with a minimal potential to decompensate during transport. Example: a patient with no IV or an IV lock who is being transported for diagnostic testing, a stable patient being discharged from a hospital to their residence, long-term care facility, or rehabilitation facility, or transportation to and from a dialysis center.
ALS A stable patient as above with IV fluids infusing without additive medications.
Example: a patient with maintenance IV fluids running.
Paramedic A patient who has been stabilized as much as possible, but may decompensate during transport. Such a patient has no medications or technology beyond the scope of practice of the highest licensed EMS healthcare professional in attendance. Example: a cardiac patient with heparin and IV nitroglycerin infusing.
Critical Care A patient with an injury or illness who is, or may become, unstable during transport and requires care beyond the scope of practice of the highest r licensed EMS healthcare professional in attendance, and/or may develop complications requiring interventions beyond the scope of practice of the
- highest licensed EMS healthcare professional in attendance, or requires care and monitoring beyond the capabilities or scope of practice of a solo EMS healthcare professional licensed at the highest level. Example: a ventilated patient receiving two or more vasopressors and IV sedation.
• The transferring medical healthcare professional is responsible for ensuring the patient is aligned with appropriate transport personnel and technology resources based on their classification.
• The following details appropriate transport resources: Table
Class Staffing Vehicle BLS EMT + EMR or driver BLS
ALS A,C, P ALS
Paramedic P ALS
Critical Care A,C,P + MD, DO, NP, PA, RN ALS
• If an ALS unit is required and the sending facility has made a reasonable effort to obtain an
ALS unit and is unable to obtain one due to time constraints, a BLS unit may be used, providing that appropriate supplies, equipment (Table 2), and verbal/written orders have been provided and staff qualified to provide expected care accompany the patient.
• For Classes BLS, ALS and Paramedic transfers, the highest licensed EMS healthcare professional will assume ultimate authority for patient treatment within the scope of the appropriate RI Statewide EMS Protocols and Standing Orders during the transport.
• For Critical Care transfers, the ultimate authority rests with the sending physician or licensed independent healthcare professional unless the critical care team includes physician, in which case authority shall be shared and care will be provided in collaborative nature. The critical care staff shall be responsible for care beyond that of the scope of the EMS healthcare professionals present. The EMS healthcare professionals present retain their authority for EMS care under their scope as defined in the Rhode Island Statewide EMS Protocols and Standing Orders. If questions arise or guidance is needed, contact the sending healthcare professional or MEDICAL CONTROL.
• All patients intubated with an endotracheal tube or other advanced airway shall have continuous waveform capnography monitoring in place during transfer/ transport. Table 2 - Equipment for Transfer Using a BLS Vehicle
• 1 - Bag Normal Saline (1000 ml) • Glucagon
• 1 - Bag Lactated Ringer’s (1000ml) • Hydrocortisone (injectable)
• 1- 60 drop IV administration set • Levophed
• 1 - 10 or 20 drop IV admin set • Lidocaine
• IV catheters (3 each 14, 16, 18, 20g) • Magnesium sulfate
• Manual defibrillator with monitor • Sodium bicarbonate
• Adenosine • Naloxone
• Amiodarone • Nitroglycerin (tabs or lingual
• Calcium chloride or gluconate spray)
• Dextrose 10% (250 ml bag)
• Midazolam
• Diphenhydramine (PO)
• Diphenhydramine (injectable)
• Dopamine
• Epinephrine 1:1000
• Epinephrine 1:10,000
• Fentanyl
• Furosemide
-
• In addition to the pharmacologic agents contained within the RI Statewide EMS
Protocols and Standing Orders, paramedics may transport any patient receiving heparin and stroke patients receiving tissue plasminogen activator, nicardipine and labetalol, or who received TNK.
• Paramedics may transport patients receiving IV antibiotics, any variation of crystalloid IV solutions and IV infusions of insulin, octreotide, vasopressin, or those containing electrolytes (potassium, magnesium, calcium, potassium phosphate, sodium phosphate). Potassium infusions >10 mEq/hr (maximum mEq/hr) require continuous ECG monitoring.
• All infusions, unless otherwise exempted in these protocols and standing orders must be delivered by electronic infusion pump.
• Paramedics who have completed a CEMS and service medical director approved blood and blood component competency program may transport patients receiving blood and blood products.
• Paramedics who have completed a CEMS and service medical director approved chest drainage system competency program may transport patients requiring a . chest drainage system.

06.06.title: Patient in Police Custody
06.06.content:
Recognition:
• Patient in the custody of law enforcement or correctional personnel.
• Routine patient care.
• For patients with a compliant/evidence of traumatic injury or medical illness, manage per appropriate protocol(s).
• For patients with a presentation consistent with delirium with agitation, manage per the Delirium with Agitation Protocol.
• If the patient has been exposed to aerosolized oleoresin capsicum (OC, Cap-Stun®): Move patient to fresh air if possible and appropriate. Remove contaminated clothing while preserving privacy. Discourage the patient from rubbing their eyes or other affected areas. Reassure the patient that the effects are temporary and should abate within minutes. Have the patient blow their nose to aid in dislodging residual irritant. Irrigate the face/eyes with NORMAL SALINE or water. If the patient is experiencing dyspnea or wheezing, manage per the age appropriate Respiratory Distress Protocol.
○ Patients with without dyspnea or wheezing, but with a history of asthma or
COPD, should be monitored for a period of 20 minutes.
• For patients that have been subjected to a conductive energy weapon (CEW)
[Taser©]:
If CEW probes are embedded in sensitive/vulnerable areas (above the level of the clavicles, genitalia, female breasts) or if there is suspicion of probe penetration into bone or vasculature, the probes should not be removed by EMS healthcare professionals. In this case, the patient should be transported for evaluation and probe removal.
CEW probes embedded subcutaneously in non-sensitive areas of skin may be removed by EMS healthcare professionals as follows: ti
E 1. Ensure wires are disconnected from the CEW.
2. Stabilize the skin around the embedded probe using the non-dominant hand.
3. Grasp the probe by the metal body using the dominant hand.
4. Remove the probe in a single quick motion.
5. Wipe the wound with chlorohexidine or alcohol and apply a dressing.
6. Treat probes as a sharps hazard and dispose of properly (law enforcement may be required to take possession of the probes).
7. Patients should be referred accordingly for follow up based on their tetanus immunization status.
8. Patients who have been exposed to > 3 CEW cycles, to the effects of >1 CEW or a continuous CEW cycle of > 15 seconds should have ECG monitoring and .
be transported for evaluation.
• Transport the patient to the nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility.
NOTES:
• Patients in police custody retain the right to participate in decision making regarding their medical care and may request or refuse medical care of EMS.
• Patients restrained by law enforcement devices must be transported accompanied by law enforcement/correctional personnel in the patient compartment capable of removing the devices. When EMS healthcare professionals use restraining devices in accordance with the
Patient Restraint Procedure Protocol, law enforcement personnel may follow behind the ambulance during transport if there are no safety concerns and the arrangement is agreeable to both EMS and law enforcement personnel on scene.
• If restraints are applied by law enforcement personnel, EMS healthcare professionals are required to follow the Patient Restraint Procedure Protocol with regard to monitoring and documentation.
• Never position or transport any restrained patient in such a way that could negatively impact the patient’s respiratory or circulatory status.
• If an asthmatic patient is exposed to OC and released to law enforcement, all parties should be advised to immediately contact EMS if wheezing or respiratory distress develop.
ti

06.07.title: Specialized Patient Care
06.07.content:
Recognition:
• Patient requiring specialized healthcare needs.
• Routine patient care.
• Attempt to contact the person most knowledgeable about the patient’s specialized health care needs in order to obtain advice during the care and transport process.
• Determine if an Emergency Care Plan (ECP) is present. The ECP must include:
Patient identification, including photograph;
A brief description of the patient’s specialized care needs;
Instructions for care in anticipated emergency situations;
Reference numbers for further information; and the Filing and effective date from the Department of Health.
• If an ECP IS present, follow the ECP and transport the patient as indicated.
• If no ECP present, and the patient is attached to portable special medical equipment that appears to be working properly, transport it with the patient.
• If the equipment is either too large to transport or does not appear to be working properly, consult MEDICAL CONTROL for guidance. It may be necessary to as safely as possible remove the equipment from the patient and provide alternative support as indicated.
• If the patient has a specialized health care need not related to equipment, follow r the instructions of the ECP.
• If there is an ECP, it should be kept with the patient during transport. t
• If available, the person most knowledgeable about the patient’s specialized health ti care needs should accompany the patient during transport.
• Transport the patient to nearest appropriate Hospital Emergency Facility. If an ECP specifies a particular hospital, comply with that direction if possible.
E i

06.08.title: Termination of Resuscitation Efforts
06.08.content:
Recognition:
• Pulseless and apneic patient undergoing resuscitative efforts meeting the criteria below.
1. Paramedic level EMS healthcare professionals may terminate resuscitative efforts
in the field if ALL of the following criteria are met:
a. Patient is ≥ 16 years of age (or a patient less ≤ 16 if the parent(s) is/are agreeable);
b. Persistent asystole or agonal rhythm (rate ≤ 20) is present and no reversible causes have been identified and high quality, minimally interrupted CPR has been performed for a minimum of 30 minutes or a minimum of ≥ 40 minutes when other underlying ECG rhythms are present;
c. NO SHOCKABLE RHYTHM WITHIN THE LAST 10 MINUTES.
d. The airway has been successfully managed with verification of device
) placement, including continuous waveform capnography. Acceptable management techniques include BIAD, endotracheal intubation (oral or nasal), or cricothyrotomy; ( e. IV or IO access has been achieved;
f. Rhythm appropriate pharmacologic and electrical therapy has been administered according to applicable protocols; ff g. Patient is not profoundly hypothermic;
h. All possible reversible etiologies have been considered and managed.
2. When considering TOR, consider allowing the family to be present during ti resuscitative efforts as appropriate.
3. MEDICAL CONTROL may be consulted at any time when considering TOR. If
MEDICAL CONTROL was consulted, document the name of the physician consulted.
4. Follow protocol 06.09 Deceased Persons.
5. The paramedic invoking this protocol must author the patient care report. f ti
NOTES:
• Resuscitative efforts shall NOT be terminated in a patient with a shockable rhythm (VF/VT) unless authorized by MEDICAL CONTROL.

06.09.title: Deceased Persons
06.09.content:
Recognition:
• Patient encountered by EMS healthcare professionals who meets the criteria for biological death.
• Patient with MOLST / Comfort One in place who is pulseless and apneic.
• Patient with other approved advanced directive requiring no CPR be administered who is pulseless and apneic.
• Patient for whom resuscitative efforts are terminated on scene by paramedic level EMS healthcare professionals.
1. Once a determination of death has been made by EMS healthcare professionals, notify the law enforcement agency having jurisdiction.
2. If the death is of a suspicious nature:
a. Follow the direction of law enforcement personnel;
b. Limit the number of EMS healthcare professionals and their activities at the immediate scene to preserve the integrity of the scene; and c. Provide any requested or relevant information to law enforcement personnel.
3. If the determination of death has been made following the termination of resuscitation (TOR) in the field, leave all lines, tubes, and other therapeutic devices
(electrical therapy pads, ECG electrodes, etc.) in place until it is known if the case will be accepted by the Office of the State Medical Examiner (OSME). If any devices were removed during resuscitative efforts for any reason, tape them across the chest of the patient. Do not place sharps under tape but rather note the devices in writing on the tape.
4. Death occurring from any of the following must be referred to the OSME and the
law enforcement agency having jurisdiction is responsible for notifying the OSME:
a. Death is due to, or there is a suspicion of, accident, homicide, suicide, or trauma of any nature;
b. Death is sudden in a public place;
E c. Death is from a drug or toxic substance;
d. Death is sudden and unattended (patient without a primary care physician who apparently dies of natural causes, aka “natural death”);
e. Death is related to a job, work place or environment; .
f. Death occurs during, or immediately after, surgery, diagnostic or therapeutic procedure.
5. If the death is an attended death (the patient has an active primary care physician and has died of apparently natural causes) and the death does not meet any of the
criteria in #4 above:
a. A reasonable effort should be made by EMS to notify the patient’s primary care physician of the death. It is preferred, but not mandatory, to communicate directly with the primary care physician prior to releasing the body.
b. Document any communication with the patient’s primary care physician in the
EMS patient care report (PCR) and provide the name of the physician who will be signing the death certificate to law enforcement.
c. If unable to make contact with the patient’s primary care physician, provide the name of the physician and his/her contact information to law enforcement personnel.
d. The body may be released to a funeral home. If the body is released to funeral home (not the medical examiner’s office), EMS healthcare professionals may remove any medical interventions, i.e., IV/IO, advanced airways, etc.
6. In certain circumstances (public area, highway or roadway), law enforcement may authorize the movement of a deceased person from the immediate scene. Once determination of death has been made at the scene, deceased persons are not to be transported to any facility (hospital, funeral home, OSME) in an ambulance.
7. EMS healthcare professionals should:
a. Maintain respect for the deceased and their family;
b. Provide emotional support for bystanders and family members as appropriate;
and c. Assist family members in contacting other family members, friends or others for emotional support.

06.10.title: Immunizations
06.10.content:
Recognition:
• Patient requiring immunization.
Indications:
• Public health or public safety incident.
• As part of a CEMS approved mobile integrated health-community paramedicine (MIH-CP) program, with standing orders from the medical director of the MIH-CP program.
Immunizations:
Immunizations listed in this protocol must be administered according to the Centers for Disease
Control and Prevention (CDC) Advisory Committee for Immunization Practices (ACIP) guidelines.
The list of routinely recommended vaccines differs for adults and children. For the purposes of immunizations, adults are persons who are 19 years of age or older; children are persons years of age or younger. The vaccines that can be administered under this protocol are listed indicated.
• Anthrax
• DTaP (diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis)
• Hepatitis
• Hepatitis B
• Inactivated polio vaccine
• Influenza ti
• MMR (measles, mumps, rubella)
• Meningococcal vaccine i
• Pneumococcal vaccine
• Rabies
• SARS-CoV-2 vaccine
• Shingles vaccine
• Smallpox vaccine
• Tetanus
• Varicella (chickenpox)
• Yellow fever
Public Health Emergency declared by the RI Department of Health
E • Paramedic, Advanced EMT-Cardiac, Advanced EMT and Emergency Medical Technician (EMT) healthcare professionals may administer vaccinations that are authorized by a standing order as part of structured immunization program (i.e., medical emergency distribution system point-of-dispensing [MEDS-POD]) when the program is instituted as the result of a public health emergency response declared by the RI Department of Health (RIDOH).
EMTs shall complete a course in vaccine administration and a course specific to the vaccine being provided, prior to performing in that role. All EMS healthcare professionals are strongly urged to also take these courses.
C EMTs shall work under the direct supervision of the assigned Medical Director for the MEDS-POD event.
NOTES:
• For vaccine specific education, go to the U.S. CDC COVID-19 Vaccine Training Modules web site. Upload the course completion certificate to your individual TRAIN and ImageTrend accounts.
• The vaccine administration course, including psychomotor skills verification, must be approved by the Medical Director of the EMS agency or MEDS-POD. Mobile Integrated Health-Community Paramedicine Vaccination Program
• Advanced EMT-Cardiac healthcare professionals may administer seasonal influenza and SARS CoV-2 vaccinations as authorized by a standing order as part of a CEMS approved MIH-CP program.
• Paramedic healthcare professionals may administer vaccinations listed on the previous page and as authorized by a standing order as part of a CEMS approved MIH-CP program.
• Paramedic or Advanced EMT-Cardiac level EMS agencies operating a MIH-CP program that includes the administration of seasonal influenza vaccine must enroll in the Rhode Island State Supplied Vaccine (SSV) program.
• EMS agencies enrolled in the State Supplied Vaccine program and authorized to administer vaccines are required to electronically report to the Department of Health’s Child and Adult Immunization Registry. Reporting must occur on all vaccines administered within a seven (7) day period after administration in the format required by RIDOH. Vaccine administration procedure to be followed
1. Ensure that the potential immunization recipient is assessed for contraindications to immunizations.
2. Inform the recipient of the potential side effects and adverse reactions, orally and in writing, prior to immunization, and inform each potential immunization recipient, in ti
C writing, of the appropriate course of action in the event of an untoward or adverse event. Vaccine Information Statements (VIS), developed by the Centers for Disease i
Control and Prevention (CDC), United States Department of Health and Human
P Services are to be used. https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/vis/index.html
3. Before the immunization is administered, obtain informed consent from the recipient.
4. In the case of children and persons incapable of providing consent to immunization, consent may be gained by informing the legally responsible person of the potential side effects and adverse reactions in writing and by obtaining a written consent prior to administering the immunization.
5. Provide to each legally responsible immunization recipient a signed certificate of
immunization noting the:
• Recipient’s name and address
• Date of immunization
• Name and license number of the administering EMS healthcare professional.
• Immunizing agent, manufacturer and lot number.
6. Medications for the treatment of allergic reactions and anaphylaxis including, but not limited to, epinephrine and the necessary syringes and needles must be immediately available.

06.11.title: Naloxone Leave Behind
06.11.content:
Recognition:
• Increase access to naloxone following suspected overdose reversal. EMS healthcare professionals may leave intranasal naloxone and instructions for patients who are at high risk for opioid overdose. Naloxone intranasal delivery devices may also be pro- vided to patients whose medication regimen includes opioids, at-risk family members, at-risk companions and friends and/or bystanders, even if the call does not specifical- ly involve an opioid overdose.
A naloxone overdose prevention kit may be provided to:
• Patients who refuse treatment and/or transport.
• Patient’s family member, companion or friend when a patient is treated and/or trans- ported.
• As a replacement for bystander/layperson who provided intranasal naloxone prior to
EMS arrival.
• An individual requesting intranasal naloxone on scene or at a designated Safe Station. Following a suspected opioid overdose reversal with naloxone, EMS healthcare profes-
sionals should:
• Encourage transport for further evaluation and care. If an alert and oriented patient refuses care and transportation, document the refusal per the Documentation proto- col in the PCR.
• Provide recovery referral information provided in the Toxicological Emergencies - Gen- eral Protocol.
E • Offer a naloxone Overdose Prevention Kit.
• If intranasal naloxone is left with patient or other party, EMS shall provide instruction on the indications and proper technique for using the device and hands-only CPR.
• Advise that 911 should be called in suspected overdose situations.
• Document any kit distribution in the PCR or REDCap for tracking and data collection. https://surveys.health.ri.gov/redcap/surveys/?s=DHX8Y9MKLPJDFK73 or
Scan the REDCap QR Code to document:
A naloxone overdose prevention kit should contain the following:
• Two intranasal naloxone delivery devices each containing 4mg doses.
• Instructions for opioid overdose identification and naloxone use.
• Recovery resource information provided in the Toxicological Emergencies - General
Protocol.

06.12.title: Special Projects Waiver
06.12.content:
Recognition:
At the discretion of the Rhode Island Department Health (RIDOH) Center for Emergency Medical Services (CEMS), protocols established in this document may be waived or modified for special projects that demonstrate innovative delivery of emergency medical services care. Proposals for special projects must be submitted to CEMS in writing, a copy of which shall then be forwarded to the Ambulance Service Coordinating Advisory Board (ASCAB); and no protocol requirements will be waived or modified without explicit CEMS and ASCAB approval. Special projects will be consid- ered experimental in nature and will be afforded a probationary review period of six (6) months.
Review of special projects will continue quarterly after the initial probationary review period and progress reports shall be submitted to at that time to CEMS, copies of which shall then be for- warded to the ASCAB. Renewal submission will be required annually. CEMS reserves the right to deny or revoke any special project waiver at any point, for any reason. Any modifications to an existing and approved special project waiver must be submitted in writing and approved by CEMS and the ASCAB prior to the implementation of the requested modification.
Application Requirements:
1. EMS agency and contact information
• Name and information of program director: address, phone number and e-mail.
• Name and information of Medical Director: address, phone number and e-mail.
• Hospital and healthcare facilities involved with project, if applicable.
2. Detailed description of proposed special project
• Purpose of the special project and goals.
• Level of care involved with the project.
• Number of healthcare professionals involved in the project.
• Description of population to be served by the special project.
• Description of the need and demand for the special project.
• Outline detailed standards of the special project and requirements of personnel oper- ating under special project waiver, to include a detailed list of all required positions, titles and required number of staff.
• Provide a detailed outline of staffing needs and how the special project will successfully . meet the staffing needs.
• Provide a list of required vehicles and vehicle types. All vehicles must be licensed by
CEMS prior to approval.
• Provide a detailed list of all equipment and medications needed for the special project.
• Outline, in detail, the required education, and/or additional certifications required for the special project, including a detailed education plan, which shall include the timeframe for education and/or the certification process. The education plan must be approved by the CEMS Training Coordinator via the TRAIN.org learning management system. All submissions must be made thirty (30) days in advance. Proof of completion for each EMS healthcare professional shall be provided prior to the special project waiver approval.
• Outline a detailed implementation plan for the special project.
• Provide documentation of the special projects implemented in other states compara- ble to the project.
• Provide an outline of safety and efficacy of the proposed project, including a descrip- tion of how public health and safety or individual patient care will not be compromised by the special project.
• Outline an effective continuous quality improvement (CQI) plan and on-going review of the special project, with timeframes, guidelines, and evaluation tools. Include individual names who will be responsible for CQI. This section shall include a description of factors that would mandate that the special project waiver designation be terminated.
• Include a letter of support from the EMS agency medical director, including, in detail, the functions the medical director will perform for the special project, e.g., performing
3. Review of application:
• Applications may be submitted at any time. CEMS shall review all applications for spe- cial projects within seven (7) days of receipt and determine if application is complete. If the application for the special project is found to be incomplete, CEMS with notify the project director and enumerate the missing requirements.
• For received and completed applications, the Chief of EMS and medical director will review the application and make recommendations on the relevant clinical aspects of the special project as needed.
• If the proposal for special project is approved, CEMS will require proof of completion for any education required for the special project prior to allowing the EMS agency to implement a special project.
• Approvals are not final until signed by the Chief of EMS and CEMS medical director.
4. Conduct of special project waiver:
• No special project will commence until applicant receives written authorization from
CEMS.
• CEMS reserves the right to deny approval if the applicant commences the special pro- ject prior to explicit written approval from CEMS. The EMS agency that initiates a spe- cial project without approval may be subject to disciplinary action.
• CEMS may attach or modify conditions to special projects,. i
• Special projects will be required to submit progress reports and data quarterly. Failure to do so may result in revocation of approval and/or consideration for renewal.
• Special projects, if approved, will be given a six (6) month probationary review period.
Prior to the conclusion of the probationary review period, the project shall be present- ed to ASCAB for review and approval. If the parameters of the project are met during the probationary period, and CEMS and the ASCAB have approved the continuation of the special project, approval for the special project may be granted for one year. An update and review shall be presented to the ASCAB every six months for the duration of the special project. All special projects shall be approved in six-month increments by
CEMS and the ASCAB. A renewal application must be submitted annually, sixty days pri- or to the renewal date.
• Once approved and implemented, any modification to a special project waiver may on- ly be made with explicit approval of CEMS. Requests for modifications must be made in writing to CEMS. The EMS agency must receive written approval from CEMS prior to implementing any modifications to the special project. An EMS agency that initiates modification to special project prior to approval may be subject to disciplinary action.
5. Circumstances for denial, suspension or revocation:
• The special project is a threat to public health and safety.
• Conduct of the project fails to adhere to the terms and conditions of the special project waiver.
• The director of the special project fails to submit required data and progress reports in the proper timeframe.
• The director of the special project fails to cooperate with CEMS. The EMS agency demonstrates negligence in implementation or performance.
EMS healthcare professionals demonstrate unprofessional conduct.
Any discrepancy in the terms outlined in this protocol.
• Approval of a special project waiver is subject to CEMS discretion. Denial of the special project waiver is not subject to administrative appeal. CEMS will notify the EMS agency of the reason for denial. The EMS agency may reapply at any point.

07.01.title: Airway - CPAP
07.01.content:
07.01 Airway - Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)
Indication:
• Acute decompensated heart failure/cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
• Respiratory distress/hypoxic respiratory failure associated with asthma/COPD, pneumonia, or near drowning.
Contraindications:
• Respiratory arrest/agonal breathing
• Patient unable to maintain airway
• GCS < 8 or patient unable to follow commands
• Vomiting or active upper GI hemorrhage
)
• Facial fractures or deformities prohibiting adequate mask seal
• Pneumothorax
Background:
(
Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is a method of delivering oxygen via a positive pressure. CPAP raises inspiratory pressure above atmospheric pressure and r maintains the pressure during exhalation. CPAP is easily delivered in the field. CPAP has been shown to decrease to the need for endotracheal intubation in cardiogenic pulmonary and is considered a first line treatment for cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
CPAP is also useful in the management of respiratory distress and hypoxic respiratory failure associated with asthma, COPD, pneumonia and near drowning.
Procedure:
1. Ensure all necessary equipment is available, assembled and functional. Select appropriate mask size for patient.
2. Connect CPAP device to oxygen source and be sure oxygen is flowing.
ti
3. Explain procedure to the patient.
4. Consider placing a nasopharyngeal airway.
5. With oxygen flowing, place the mask over the patient’s mouth and nose and secure the mask with the provided straps starting with the lower strap until there s is minimal or no air leak.
6. Select appropriate liter flow or adjust setting on the CPAP device to delivery desired level of PEEP. Start at zero and titrate upward based on pathology and ti patient response to a maximum of 10 cmH 0 (5-10 cmH 0 for pulmonary edema, near drowning, aspiration, pneumonia, 3-5 2 cmH 0 for ast 2 hma or COPD).
7. Evaluate patient response by assessing breath sounds, SpO
, vital signs and
- general appearance.
8. If the administration of nebulized medication (albuterol) is required, follow device manufactures instructions.
9. If the patient’s condition stabilizes, maintain CPAP for transportation. Provide the receiving facility with early notification of a patient requiring transition to hospital CPAP.
10. Discontinue CPAP and provide airway management/ventilator support as
indicated if any of the following occur:
A decreased in the SpO (worsening hypoxia) from the initial reading when
CPAP was applied;
Agonal breathing/respiratory arrest;
Decreased LOC (GCS < 8); or
Pneumothorax.
D ocument CPAP settings, patient’s response and serial SpO , vital signs and capnography readings.
NOTES:
• Close patient monitoring is required during the application of CPAP.
• Patients receiving CPAP may require coaching. Patients should be encourage to breathe slowly and deeply. The patient should be encourage to allow forced ventilation to occur.

07.02.title: Airway - Foreign Body Airway Obstruction
07.02.content:
Indication:
• Foreign body airway obstruction as evidenced by display of the universal choking sign, signs of poor air exchange and increased breathing difficulty, such as silent cough, cyanosis, or the inability to speak or breathe.
• Inability to provide positive pressure ventilation in a patient in respiratory or cardiac arrest after repositioning of the airway or placement of a BIAD.
Contraindications:
• None
Background:
FBAO occurs most commonly in adults while eating. In children FBAO may occur while eating or playing. Most FBAO events are witnessed by bystanders and there is usually some intervention by bystanders prior to the arrival of EMS. In some
) instances, however, FBAO may be unwitnessed and the patient is encountered by unresponsive and in respiratory or cardiac arrest. In this instance, the presence of FBAO may only be recognized by the inability or difficulty in providing positive pressure ventilation. (
Procedure:
ti
Conscious Patient
1. Assess the patient to determine if the FBAO is complete (unable to speak) or partial (able to speak and or cough, displaying universal choking sign).
2. Do not interfere with a patient who has a mild/partial FBAO who is able to cough.
Allow the patient to clear their airway by coughing and monitor closely.
3. For an infant, deliver five back blows followed by five chest thrusts repeatedly until the object is expelled or the patient becomes unresponsive. If the patient becomes unresponsive, manage as below in Unresponsive Patient. i
E 4. For a child, perform sub-diaphragmatic abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) until the object is expelled or the patient becomes unresponsive. If the patient becomes unresponsive, manage as below in Unresponsive Patient.
5. For an adult, perform sub-diaphragmatic abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver) until the object is expelled or the patient becomes unresponsive. Chest thrusts should be used in obese patients and in patients who are in the late stages of pregnancy. If the patient becomes unresponsive, manage as below in Unresponsive Patient.
- Unresponsive Patient
1. Safely lower the patient to a hard surface.
2. Initiate CPR and resuscitative efforts following the age appropriate Cardiac
Arrest Protocol.
3. Each time the airway is opened/accessed during CPR it should be observed for r the presence of a foreign body. Do not perform blind finger sweeps.
4. Appropriately trained and licensed AC and P level practitioners should perform direct laryngoscopy to potentially identify and remove the foreign body utilizing .
Magill forceps and or suction*.
5. Provide airway management per the age appropriate Airway Management
Protocol.
*Appropriately trained and licensed AEMT-C level healthcare professionals practicing within a service/system that does not include endotracheal intubation as part of the service/system scope of practice may still perform direct laryngoscopy and utilize Magill forceps for the purposes of foreign body airway obstruction removal.

07.03.title: Airway - Endotracheal Intubation (Oral)
07.03.content:
Indication:
• Cardiac arrest, apnea or hypoventilation (AEMT-C level for patients >8 y.o. with apnea or cardiac arrest only)
• Patient with loss of airway protective reflexes (ability to cough, swallow) or airway compromise (paramedic only)
• Patient with inhalation or other injury with potential for evolving airway compromise (paramedic only)
Contraindications:
• None
Background:
